Studies involving carbon monoxide have been conducted in many laboratories throughout the world for its anti-inflammatory and cytoprotective properties. These properties have potential to be used to prevent the development of a series of pathological conditions including ischemia reperfusion injury, transplant rejection, atherosclerosis, severe sepsis, severe malaria, or autoimmunity. Clinical tests involving humans have been performed, however the results have not yet been released.<ref name="clinical-trial">{{Cite news|title=Poison gas may carry a medical benefit|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2009/10/16/poison_gas_may_carry_a_medical_benefit/?page=full|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=October 16, 2009|accessdate=October 16, 2009 | first=Carolyn Y. | last=Johnson}}</ref>
== Carbon suboxide ==
[[File:Carbon suboxide macrocyclic polymers.gif|thumb|Those are 6- or 8-ring macrocyclic polymers of carbon suboxide that were found in living organisms. They are acting as an endogenous digoxin-like Na+/K+-ATP-ase and Ca-dependent ATP-ase inhibitors, endogenous natriuretics, antioxidants and antihypertensives]]
[[Carbon suboxide]], C<sub>3</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, can be produced in small amounts in any biochemical process that normally produces [[carbon monoxide]], CO, for example, during heme oxidation by heme oxygenase-1. It can also be formed from malonic acid. It has been shown that carbon suboxide in an organism can quickly polymerize into macrocyclic polycarbon structures with the common formula (C<sub>3</sub>O<sub>2</sub>)<sub>n</sub> (mostly (C<sub>3</sub>O<sub>2</sub>)<sub>6</sub> and (C<sub>3</sub>O<sub>2</sub>)<sub>8</sub>), and that those macrocyclic compounds are potent inhibitors of Na<sup>+</sup>/K<sup>+</sup>-ATP-ase and Ca-dependent ATP-ase, and have [[digoxin]]-like physiological properties and natriuretic and antihypertensive actions. Those macrocyclic carbon suboxide polymer compounds are thought to be endogenous digoxin-like regulators of Na<sup>+</sup>/K<sup>+</sup>-ATP-ases and Ca-dependent ATP-ases, and endogenous natriuretics and antihypertensives.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors = Kerek F|title=The structure of the digitalislike and natriuretic factors identified as macrocyclic derivatives of the inorganic carbon suboxide.|url=https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/hypres1992/23/Supplement/23_Supplement_S33/_pdf|journal=Hypertension Research|date=Sep 2000|volume=23|issue=Suppl S33|pages=S33–38|doi=10.1291/hypres.23.Supplement_S33|pmid=11016817}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Stimac R, Kerek F, Apell HJ |title=Macrocyclic carbon suboxide oligomers as potent inhibitors of the Na,K-ATPase.|journal=Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences|date=Apr 2003|volume=986|issue=1|pages=327–329|doi=10.1111/j.1749-6632.2003.tb07204.x|pmid=12763840|bibcode = 2003NYASA.986..327S |url=http://nbn-resolving.de/urn:nbn:de:bsz:352-opus-39416}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|vauthors = Kerek F, Stimac R, Apell HJ, Freudenmann F, Moroder L |title=Characterization of the macrocyclic carbon suboxide factors as potent Na,K-ATPase and SR Ca-ATPase inhibitors.|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0005273602006090|journal=Biochimica et Biophysica Acta (BBA) - Biomembranes|date=23 December 2002|volume=1567|issue=1–2|pages=213–220|doi=10.1016/S0005-2736(02)00609-0|pmid=12488055}}</ref> Other than that, some authors think also that those macrocyclic compounds of carbon suboxide can possibly diminish free radical formation and oxidative stress and play a role in endogenous anticancer protective mechanisms, for example in the [[retina]].<ref>{{cite journal|author=Tubaro E.|title=Carbon suboxide, the probable precursor of an antitumor cellular sustance: retina|language=italian|journal=Boll Chim Farm|date=Jun 1966|volume=105|issue=6|pages=415–416|pmid=6005012}}</ref>
== Hydrogen sulfide ==
{{main|Biological functions of hydrogen sulfide}}
Hydrogen sulfide is produced in small amounts by some cells of the [[mammal]]ian body and has a number of biological signaling functions. (Only two other such gases are currently known: [[nitric oxide]] (NO) and [[carbon monoxide]] (CO).)
The gas is produced from [[cysteine]] by the [[enzyme]]s [[cystathionine beta-synthase]] and [[cystathionine gamma-lyase]]. It acts as a relaxant of [[smooth muscle]] and as a [[vasodilator]]<ref name="lefer" /> and is also active in the [[brain]], where it increases the response of the [[NMDA receptor]] and facilitates [[long term potentiation]],<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1385/MN:26:1:013 | volume = 26 | issue = 1 | pages = 13–19 | last = Kimura | first = Hideo | title = Hydrogen sulfide as a neuromodulator | journal = Molecular Neurobiology | year = 2002 | pmid = 12392053 }}</ref> which is involved in the formation of memory.
Eventually the gas is converted to sulfite in the [[mitochondria]] by thiosulfate reductase, and the sulfite is further oxidized to [[thiosulfate]] and [[sulfate]] by [[sulfite oxidase]]. The sulfates are excreted in the urine.<ref name="Kamoun">{{Cite journal | volume = 20 | issue = 6–7 | pages = 697–700 | last = Kamoun | first = Pierre | title = H<sub>2</sub>S, a new neuromodulator | journal = Médecine/Sciences | date = July 2004 | pmid = 15329822 | doi = 10.1051/medsci/2004206-7697 }}</ref>
Due to its effects similar to [[nitric oxide]] (without its potential to form [[peroxides]] by interacting with [[superoxide]]), hydrogen sulfide is now recognized as potentially protecting against cardiovascular disease.<ref name="lefer">{{cite journal |last=Lefer |first=David J. |date=November 2007 |title= A new gaseous signaling molecule emerges: Cardioprotective role of hydrogen sulfide |journal=PNAS |volume=104|pages=17907–17908 |id= |url=http://www.pnas.org/content/104/46/17907.full |accessdate= 2008-09-26 |doi=10.1073/pnas.0709010104 |pmid=17991773 |issue=46 |pmc=2084269|bibcode = 2007PNAS..10417907L }}</ref> The cardioprotective role effect of [[garlic]] is caused by [[catabolism]] of the [[polysulfides|polysulfide group]] in [[allicin]] to {{chem|H|2|S}}, a reaction that could depend on reduction mediated by [[glutathione]].<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0705710104 | volume = 104 | issue = 46 | pages = 17977–17982 | last = Benavides | first = Gloria A | first2 = Giuseppe L |last2=Squadrito |first3=Robert W |last3=Mills |first4=Hetal D |last4=Patel |first5=T Scott |last5=Isbell |first6=Rakesh P |last6=Patel |first7=Victor M |last7=Darley-Usmar |first8=Jeannette E |last8=Doeller |first9=David W |last9=Kraus |author7link=Victor Darley-Usmar | title = Hydrogen sulfide mediates the vasoactivity of garlic | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | date = 2007-11-13 | pmid = 17951430 | pmc = 2084282 | bibcode =2007PNAS..10417977B }}</ref>
Though both [[nitric oxide]] (NO) and hydrogen sulfide have been shown to relax blood vessels, their mechanisms of action are different: while NO activates the enzyme [[guanylyl cyclase]], {{chem|H|2|S}} activates [[ATP-sensitive potassium channel]]s in smooth muscle cells. Researchers are not clear how the vessel-relaxing responsibilities are shared between nitric oxide and hydrogen sulfide. However, there exists some evidence to suggest that nitric oxide does most of the vessel-relaxing work in large vessels and hydrogen sulfide is responsible for similar action in smaller blood vessels.<ref name="sciam1">"[http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=toxic-gas-lifesaver Toxic Gas, Lifesaver]", ''Scientific American'', March 2010</ref>
Recent findings suggest strong cellular crosstalk of NO and {{chem|H|2|S}},<ref name="Coletta 9161–9166"/> demonstrating that the vasodilatatory effects of these two gases are mutually dependent. Additionally, {{chem|H|2|S}} reacts with intracellular [[S-Nitrosothiol|S-nitrosothiols]] to form the smallest S-nitrosothiol (HSNO), and a role of hydrogen sulfide in controlling the intracellular S-nitrosothiol pool has been suggested.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Filipovic | first1 = M. R. | last2 = Miljkovic | first2 = J. L. | last3 = Nauser | first3 = T. | last4 = Royzen | first4 = M. | last5 = Klos | first5 = K. | last6 = Shubina | first6 = T. | last7 = Koppenol | first7 = W. H. | last8 = Lippard | first8 = S. J. | last9 = Ivanović-Burmazović | first9 = I. | doi = 10.1021/ja3009693 | title = Chemical Characterization of the SmallestS-Nitrosothiol, HSNO; Cellular Cross-talk of H2S andS-Nitrosothiols | journal = Journal of the American Chemical Society | volume = 134 | issue = 29 | pages = 12016–12027 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22741609 | pmc =3408084 }}</ref>
Like nitric oxide, hydrogen sulfide is involved in the relaxation of smooth muscle that causes [[erection]] of the penis, presenting possible new therapy opportunities for [[erectile dysfunction]].<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Hydrogen sulfide as a mediator of human corpus cavernosum smooth-muscle relaxation|year=2009|journal=PNAS|doi=10.1073/pnas.0807974105|pmid=19255435|vauthors=d'Emmanuele di Villa Bianca R, Sorrentino R, Maffia P, Mirone V, Imbimbo C, Fusco F, De Palma R, Ignarro LJ, Cirino G |volume=106|issue=11|pages=4513–8|pmc=2657379|postscript=<!--None-->|bibcode = 2009PNAS..106.4513D }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.webmd.com/erectile-dysfunction/news/20090302/hydrogen-sulfide-potential-help-for-ed|title=Hydrogen Sulfide: Potential Help for ED|work=WebMD|date=March 2, 2009|postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref>
Hydrogen sulfide (H2S) deficiency can be detrimental to the vascular function after an [[myocardial infarction|acute myocardial infarction]] (AMI).<ref name="King 1–6">{{cite journal|vauthors = King AL, Polhemus DJ, Bhushan S, Otsuka H, Kondo K, Nicholson CK, Bradley JM, Islam KN, Calvert JW, Tao YX, Dugas TR, Kelley EE, Elrod JW, Huang PL, Wang R, Lefer DJ|title=Hydrogen sulfide cytoprotective signaling is endothelial nitric oxide synthase-nitric oxide dependent|journal=PNAS|volume=111|date=January 2014|issue=Early Edition|pages=1–6|doi=10.1073/pnas.1321871111|bibcode=2014PNAS..111.3182K|pmid=24516168|pmc=3939925}}</ref> AMIs can lead to cardiac dysfunction through two distinct changes; increased oxidative stress via free radical accumulation and decreased NO bioavailability.<ref name="Alp 2003 413–420">{{cite journal|last=Alp|first=Nicholas|author2=Channon|title=Regulation of endothelial nitric oxide synthase by tetrahydrobiopterin in vascular disease|journal=Journal of the American Heart Association|year=2003|volume=24|issue=3|pages=413–420|doi=10.1161/01.atv.0000110785.96039.f6|pmid=14656731}}</ref> Free radical accumulation occurs due to increased electron transport uncoupling at the active site of endothelial nitric oxide synthase (eNOS), an enzyme involved in converting L-arginine to NO.<ref name="King 1–6"/><ref name="Alp 2003 413–420"/> During an AMI, oxidative degradation of tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4), a cofactor in NO production, limits BH4 availability and limits NO productionby eNOS.<ref name="Alp 2003 413–420"/> Instead, eNOS reacts with oxygen, another cosubstrates involved in NO production. The products of eNOS are reduced to superoxides, increasing free radical production and oxidative stress within the cells.<ref name="King 1–6"/> A H2S deficiency impairs eNOS activity by limiting Akt activation and inhibiting Akt phosphorylation of the eNOSS1177 activation site.<ref name="King 1–6"/><ref name="Coletta 9161–9166">{{cite journal |vauthors = Coletta C, Papapetropoulos A, Erdelyi K, Olah G, Módis K, Panopoulos P, Asimakopoulou A, Gerö D, Sharina I, Martin E, Szabo C |title=Hydrogen sulfide and nitric oxide are mutually dependent in the regulation of angiogenesis and endothelium-dependent vasorelaxation |journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. |volume=109 |issue=23 |pages=9161–6 |year=2012 |pmid=22570497 |pmc=3384190 |doi=10.1073/pnas.1202916109| bibcode=2012PNAS..109.9161C}}</ref> Instead, Akt activity is increased to phosphorylate the eNOST495 inhibition site, downregulating eNOS production of NO.<ref name="King 1–6"/><ref name="Coletta 9161–9166"/>
H2S therapy uses a H2S donor, such as diallyl trisulfide (DATS), to increase the supply of H2S to an AMI patient. H2S donors reduce myocardial injury and reperfusion complications.<ref name="King 1–6"/> Increased H2S levels within the body will react with oxygen to produce sulfane sulfur, a storage intermediate for H2S.<ref name="King 1–6"/> H2S pools in the body attracts oxygen to react with excess H2S and eNOS to increase NO production.<ref name="King 1–6"/> With increased use of oxygen to produce more NO, less oxygen is available to react with eNOS to produce superoxides during an AMI, ultimately lowering the accumulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS).<ref name="King 1–6"/> Furthermore, decreased accumulation of ROS lowers oxidative stress in vascular smooth muscle cells, decreasing oxidative degeneration of BH4.<ref name="Alp 2003 413–420"/> Increased BH4 cofactor contributes to increased production of NO within the body.<ref name="Alp 2003 413–420"/> Higher concentrations of H2S directly increase eNOS activity through Akt activation to increase phosphorylation of the eNOSS1177 activation site, and decrease phosphorylation of the eNOST495 inhibition site.<ref name="King 1–6"/><ref name="Coletta 9161–9166"/> This phosphorylation process upregulates eNOS activity, catalyzing more conversion of L-arginine to NO.<ref name="King 1–6"/><ref name="Coletta 9161–9166"/> Increased NO production enables soluble guanylyl cyclase (sGC) activity, leading to an increased conversion of guanosine triphosphate (GTP) to 3’,5’-cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP).<ref name="Boerth 1997 245–259">{{cite journal|vauthors = Boerth NJ, Dey NB, Cornwell TL, Lincoln TM |title=Cyclic GMP-dependent protein kinase regulates vascular smooth muscle cell phenotype|journal=Journal of Vascular Research|year=1997|volume=34|issue=4|pages=245–259|doi=10.1159/000159231|pmid=9256084}}</ref> In H2S therapy immediately following an AMI, increased cGMP triggers an increase in protein kinase G (PKG) activity.<ref name="Lincoln C399–C407">{{cite journal|last=Lincoln|first=T. M.|author2=Cornwell, Taylor|title=cGMP-dependent protein kinase mediates the reduction of Ca2+ by cAMP in vascular smooth muscle cells|journal=American Journal of Physiology|date=March 1990|volume=258|issue=3|pages=C399–C407|url=http://ajpcell.physiology.org/content/258/3/C399|pmid=2156436|doi=10.1152/ajpcell.1990.258.3.C399}}</ref> PKG reduces intracellular Ca2+ in vascular smooth muscle to increase smooth muscle relaxation and promote blood flow.<ref name="Lincoln C399–C407"/> PKG also limits smooth muscle cell proliferation, reducing intima thickening following AMI injury, ultimately decreasing myocardial infarct size.<ref name="King 1–6"/><ref name="Boerth 1997 245–259"/>
In [[Alzheimer's disease]] the brain's hydrogen sulfide concentration is severely decreased.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0006-291X(02)00422-9 | volume = 293 | issue = 5 | pages = 1485–1488 | last = Eto | first = Ko | author2 =Takashi Asada |author3=Kunimasa Arima |author4=Takao Makifuchi |author5=Hideo Kimura | title = Brain hydrogen sulfide is severely decreased in Alzheimer's disease | journal = Biochemical and Biophysical Research Communications | date = 2002-05-24 | pmid = 12054683 }}</ref> In a certain rat model of [[Parkinson's disease]], the brain's hydrogen sulfide concentration was found to be reduced, and administering hydrogen sulfide alleviated the condition.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Hu | first1 = L. F. | last2 = Lu | first2 = M. | last3 = Tiong | first3 = C. X. | last4 = Dawe | first4 = G. S. | last5 = Hu | first5 = G. | last6 = Bian | first6 = J. S. | title = Neuroprotective effects of hydrogen sulfide on Parkinson's disease rat models | journal = Aging Cell | volume = 9 | issue = 2 | pages = 135–146 | year = 2010 | doi = 10.1111/j.1474-9726.2009.00543.x | pmid = 20041858 | pmc = }}</ref> In [[trisomy 21]] (Down syndrome) the body produces an excess of hydrogen sulfide.<ref name="Kamoun" /> Hydrogen sulfide is also involved in the disease process of [[diabetes mellitus type 1|type 1 diabetes]]. The [[beta cell]]s of the [[pancreas]] in type 1 diabetes produce an excess of the gas, leading to the death of these cells and to a reduced production of insulin by those that remain.<ref name="sciam1" />
In 2005, it was shown that [[mus musculus|mice]] can be put into a state of [[suspended animation]]-like [[hypothermia]] by applying a low dosage of hydrogen sulfide (81 [[parts per million|ppm]] {{chem|H|2|S}}) in the air. The breathing rate of the animals sank from 120 to 10 breaths per minute and their temperature fell from 37 °C to just 2 °C above ambient temperature (in effect, they had become [[Poikilotherm|cold-blooded]]). The mice survived this procedure for 6 hours and afterwards showed no negative health consequences.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/go/pr/fr/-/2/hi/science/nature/4469793.stm Mice put in 'suspended animation'], BBC News, 21 April 2005</ref> In 2006 it was shown that the [[blood pressure]] of mice treated in this fashion with hydrogen sulfide did not significantly decrease.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/4469793.stm Gas induces 'suspended animation'], BBC News, 9 October 2006</ref>
A similar process known as [[hibernation]] occurs naturally in many [[mammal]]s and also in [[toad]]s, but not in mice. (Mice can fall into a state called [[torpor|clinical torpor]] when food shortage occurs). If the {{chem|H|2|S}}-induced hibernation can be made to work in humans, it could be useful in the emergency management of severely injured patients, and in the conservation of donated organs. In 2008, hypothermia induced by hydrogen sulfide for 48 hours was shown to reduce the extent of brain damage caused by experimental [[stroke]] in rats.<ref name="Florian">{{cite journal |vauthors = Florian B, Vintilescu R, Balseanu AT, Buga AM, Grisk O, Walker LC, Kessler C, Popa-Wagner A |title=Long-term hypothermia reduces infarct volume in aged rats after focal ischemia |journal=Neurosci. Lett. |volume=438 |issue=2 |pages=180–5 |year=2008 |pmid=18456407 |doi=10.1016/j.neulet.2008.04.020}}</ref>
As mentioned above, hydrogen sulfide binds to [[Cytochrome c oxidase|cytochrome oxidase]] and thereby prevents oxygen from binding, which leads to the dramatic slowdown of [[metabolism]]. Animals and humans naturally produce some hydrogen sulfide in their body; researchers have proposed that the gas is used to regulate metabolic activity and body temperature, which would explain the above findings.<ref>Mark B. Roth and Todd Nystul. Buying Time in Suspended Animation. ''Scientific American, 1 June 2005</ref>
Two recent studies cast doubt that the effect can be achieved in larger mammals. A 2008 study failed to reproduce the effect in pigs, concluding that the effects seen in mice were not present in larger mammals.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Li |first=Jia |authorlink= |author2=Zhang, Gencheng |author3=Cai, Sally |author4= Redington, Andrew N |date=January 2008 |title=Effect of inhaled hydrogen sulfide on metabolic responses in anesthetized, paralyzed, and mechanically ventilated piglets |journal=[[Pediatric Critical Care Medicine]] |volume=9 |issue=1 |pages=110–112 |id= |url=http://www.pccmjournal.com/pt/re/pccm/abstract.00130478-200801000-00021.htm |accessdate= 2008-02-07 |quote=H<sub>2</sub>S does not appear to have hypometabolic effects in ambiently cooled large mammals and conversely appears to act as a hemodynamic and metabolic stimulant. |doi=10.1097/01.PCC.0000298639.08519.0C |pmid=18477923}}</ref> Likewise a paper by Haouzi et al. noted that there is no induction of hypometabolism in sheep, either.<ref name="pmid17980679">{{cite journal|vauthors=Haouzi P, Notet V, Chenuel B, Chalon B, Sponne I, Ogier V | title=H<sub>2</sub>S induced hypometabolism in mice is missing in sedated sheep | journal=Respir Physiol Neurobiol | year= 2008 | volume= 160 | issue= 1 | pages= 109–15 | pmid=17980679 | doi=10.1016/j.resp.2007.09.001 | displayauthors=etal }}</ref>
At the February 2010 [[TED (conference)|TED]] conference, [[Mark Roth (scientist)|Mark Roth]] announced that hydrogen sulfide induced hypothermia ''in humans'' had completed [[Clinical trial#Phases|Phase I]] clinical trials.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ted.com/talks/lang/eng/mark_roth_suspended_animation.html|title=Mark Roth: Suspended animation is within our grasp}}</ref> The clinical trials commissioned by the company he helped found, Ikaria, were however withdrawn or terminated by August 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=IK-1001 (Sodium Sulfide (Na2S) for Injection) in Subjects With Acute ST-Segment Elevation Myocardial Infarction|url=http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT01007461|publisher=[[ClinicalTrials.gov]]|date=2010-11-04|quote=This study has been withdrawn prior to enrollment. ( Company decision. Non-safety related )}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Reduction of Ischemia-Reperfusion Mediated Cardiac Injury in Subjects Undergoing Coronary Artery Bypass Graft Surgery|url=http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT00858936|publisher=[[ClinicalTrials.gov]]|date=2011-08-03|quote=This study has been terminated. ( Study Terminated - Company decision )}}</ref>
== Sulfur dioxide ==
The role of sulfur dioxide in mammalian biology is not yet well understood.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Liu |first=D. |url=http://benthamscience.com/mrmc/contabs/mrmc10-11.html#4 |title=Sulfur dioxide: a novel gaseous signal in the regulation of cardiovascular functions |journal=Mini-Reviews in Medicinal Chemistry |year=2010 |volume=10 |issue= 11|pages=1039–1045 |pmid=20540708 |last2=Jin |first2=H |last3=Tang |first3=C |last4=Du |first4=J |doi=10.2174/1389557511009011039}}</ref> Sulfur dioxide blocks nerve signals from the [[pulmonary stretch receptors]] and abolishes the [[Hering–Breuer reflex|Hering–Breuer inflation reflex]].
It was shown that endogenous sulfur dioxide plays a role in diminishing an experimental [[lung]] damage caused by [[oleic acid]]. Endogenous sulfur dioxide lowered lipid peroxidation, free radical formation, oxidative stress and inflammation during an experimental lung damage. Conversely, a successful lung damage caused a significant lowering of endogenous sulfur dioxide production, and an increase in lipid peroxidation, free radical formation, oxidative stress and inflammation. Moreover, blockade of an [[enzyme]] that produces endogenous SO<sub>2</sub> significantly increased the amount of lung tissue damage in the experiment. Conversely, adding [[acetylcysteine]] or [[glutathione]] to the rat diet increased the amount of endogenous SO<sub>2</sub> produced and decreased the lung damage, the free radical formation, oxidative stress, inflammation and apoptosis.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Chen S, Zheng S, Liu Z, Tang C, Zhao B, Du J, Jin H |title=Endogenous sulfur dioxide protects against oleic acid-induced acute lung injury in association with inhibition of oxidative stress in rats.|journal=Lab. Invest.|date=Feb 2015|volume=95|issue=2|pages=142–156|doi=10.1038/labinvest.2014.147|pmid=25581610}}</ref>
It is considered that endogenous sulfur dioxide plays a significant physiological role in regulating [[cardiac]] and [[blood vessel]] function, and aberrant or deficient sulfur dioxide metabolism can contribute to several different cardiovascular diseases, such as [[arterial hypertension]], [[atherosclerosis]], [[pulmonary arterial hypertension]], [[stenocardia]].<ref>{{cite journal|author=Tian H.|title=Advances in the study on endogenous sulfur dioxide in the cardiovascular system.|journal=Chin Med J|date=Nov 2014|volume=127|issue=21|pages=3803–3807|pmid=25382339}}</ref>
It was shown that in children with pulmonary arterial hypertension due to congenital heart diseases the level of [[homocysteine]] is higher and the level of endogenous sulfur dioxide is lower than in normal control children. Moreover, these biochemical parameters strongly correlated to the severity of pulmonary arterial hypertension. Authors considered homocysteine to be one of useful biochemical markers of disease severity and sulfur dioxide metabolism to be one of potential therapeutic targets in those patients.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Yang R, Yang Y, Dong X, Wu X, Wei Y |title=Correlation between endogenous sulfur dioxide and homocysteine in children with pulmonary arterial hypertension associated with congenital heart disease|language=chinese|journal=Zhonghua Er Ke Za Zhi|date=Aug 2014|volume=52|issue=8|pages=625–629|pmid=25224243}}</ref>
Endogenous sulfur dioxide also has been shown to lower the [[Cell proliferation|proliferation]] rate of endothelial [[smooth muscle]] cells in blood vessels, via lowering the [[MAPK]] activity and activating [[adenylyl cyclase]] and [[protein kinase A]].<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Liu D, Huang Y, Bu D, Liu AD, Holmberg L, Jia Y, Tang C, Du J, Jin H |title=Sulfur dioxide inhibits vascular smooth muscle cell proliferation via suppressing the Erk/MAP kinase pathway mediated by cAMP/PKA signaling.|journal=Cell Death Dis.|date=May 2014|volume=5|issue=5|pages=e1251|doi=10.1038/cddis.2014.229|pmid=24853429|pmc=4047873}}</ref> Smooth muscle cell proliferation is one of important mechanisms of hypertensive remodeling of blood vessels and their [[stenosis]], so it is an important pathogenetic mechanism in arterial hypertension and atherosclerosis.
Endogenous sulfur dioxide in low concentrations causes endothelium-dependent [[vasodilation]]. In higher concentrations it causes endothelium-independent vasodilation and has a negative inotropic effect on cardiac output function, thus effectively lowering blood pressure and myocardial oxygen consumption. The vasodilating effects of sulfur dioxide are mediated via ATP-dependent [[calcium channel]]s and L-type ("dihydropyridine") calcium channels. Endogenous sulfur dioxide is also a potent antiinflammatory, antioxidant and cytoprotective agent. It lowers blood pressure and slows hypertensive remodeling of blood vessels, especially thickening of their intima. It also regulates lipid metabolism.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Wang XB, Jin HF, Tang CS, Du JB |title=The biological effect of endogenous sulfur dioxide in the cardiovascular system.|journal=Eur J Pharmacol|date=16 Nov 2011|volume=670|issue=1|doi=10.1016/j.ejphar.2011.08.031|pmid=21925165|pages=1–6}}</ref>
Endogenous sulfur dioxide also diminishes myocardial damage, caused by [[isoproterenol]] [[adrenergic]] hyperstimulation, and strengthens the myocardial antioxidant defense reserve.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Liang Y, Liu D, Ochs T, Tang C, Chen S, Zhang S, Geng B, Jin H, Du J |title=Endogenous sulfur dioxide protects against isoproterenol-induced myocardial injury and increases myocardial antioxidant capacity in rats.|journal=Lab. Invest.|date=Jan 2011|volume=91|issue=1|pages=12–23|doi=10.1038/labinvest.2010.156|pmid=20733562}}</ref>
Sulfur dioxide expelled from the gastrointestinal tract (through the process of flatulence) is thought to be one of the main constituents to the unpleasant smell colloquially referred to as a "fart".
== Hydrogen cyanide ==
Some authors have shown that [[neuron]]s can produce [[hydrogen cyanide]] upon activation of their [[opioid]] [[receptor (biochemistry)|receptors]] by endogenous or exogenous opioids. They have also shown that neuronal production of HCN activates [[NMDA receptor]]s and plays a role in [[signal transduction]] between neuronal cells ([[neurotransmission]]). Moreover, increased endogenous neuronal HCN production under opioids was seemingly needed for adequate opioid [[analgesia]], as analgesic action of opioids was attenuated by HCN scavengers. They considered endogenous HCN to be a neuromodulator.<ref name="pmid9369328">{{cite journal|vauthors=Borowitz JL, Gunasekar PG, Isom GE |title=Hydrogen cyanide generation by mu-opiate receptor activation: possible neuromodulatory role of endogenous cyanide|journal=Brain Res.|date=12 Sep 1997|volume=768|issue=1–2|pages=294–300|pmid=9369328|doi=10.1016/S0006-8993(97)00659-8}}</ref>
It was also shown that, while stimulating [[muscarinic]] [[cholinergic]] receptors in cultured [[pheochromocytoma]] cells ''increases'' HCN production, in a living organism (''in vivo'') muscarinic cholinergic stimulation actually ''decreases'' HCN production.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Gunasekar PG, Prabhakaran K, Li L, Zhang L, Isom GE, Borowitz JL |title=Receptor mechanisms mediating cyanide generation in PC12 cells and rat brain.|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0168010204000094|journal=Neurosci Res.|date=May 2004|volume=49|issue=1|pages=13–18|doi=10.1016/j.neures.2004.01.006|pmid=15099699}}</ref>
[[Leukocyte]]s generate HCN during [[phagocytosis]].<ref name="pmid9369328" />
The [[vasodilatation]], caused by [[sodium nitroprusside]], has been shown to be mediated not only by NO generation, but also by endogenous cyanide generation, which adds not only toxicity, but also some additional antihypertensive efficacy compared to [[nitroglycerine]] and other non-cyanogenic nitrates which do not cause blood cyanide levels to rise.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Smith RP, Kruszyna H |title=Toxicology of some inorganic antihypertensive anions.|journal=Fed Proc.|date=Jan 1976|volume=35|issue=1|pages=69–72|pmid=1245233}}</ref>
== Ammonia ==
Ammonia also plays a role in both normal and abnormal animal [[physiology]]. It is biosynthesised through normal amino acid metabolism and is toxic in high concentrations.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/summary/summary.cgi?sid=10323059 |title=PubChem Substance Summary|accessdate=7 July 2009}}</ref> The [[liver]] converts ammonia to urea through a series of reactions known as the [[urea cycle]]. Liver dysfunction, such as that seen in [[cirrhosis]], may lead to elevated amounts of ammonia in the blood ([[hyperammonemia]]). Likewise, defects in the enzymes responsible for the urea cycle, such as [[ornithine transcarbamylase]], lead to hyperammonemia. Hyperammonemia contributes to the confusion and [[coma]] of [[hepatic encephalopathy]], as well as the neurologic disease common in people with urea cycle defects and [[organic aciduria]]s.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Zschocke, Johannes |author2=Georg Hoffman|title=Vademecum Metabolism|publisher= Friedrichsdorf, Germany: Milupa GmbH|year= 2004}}</ref>
Ammonia is important for normal animal acid/base balance. After formation of ammonium from [[glutamine]], [[α-ketoglutarate]] may be degraded to produce two molecules of [[bicarbonate]], which are then available as buffers for dietary acids. Ammonium is excreted in the urine, resulting in net acid loss. Ammonia may itself diffuse across the renal tubules, combine with a hydrogen ion, and thus allow for further acid excretion.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Rose, Burton |author2=Helmut Rennke|title=Renal Pathophysiology|location=Baltimore |publisher=Williams & Wilkins|year= 1994|isbn=978-0-683-07354-6}}</ref>
== Methane ==
Some authors have shown that endogenous [[methane]] is produced not only by the [[intestinal flora]] and then absorbed into the [[blood]], but also is produced - in small amounts - by [[eukaryotic]] [[cell (biology)|cells]] (during process of lipid peroxidation). And they have also shown that the endogenous methane production rises during an experimental [[mitochondria]]l [[hypoxia (medical)|hypoxia]], for example, [[sodium azide]] intoxication. They thought that methane could be one of intercellular signals of hypoxia and stress.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Eszter Tuboly |author2=Andrea Szabó |author3=Dénes Garab |author4=Gábor Bartha |author5=Ágnes Janovszky |author6=Gábor Ero″s |author7=Anna Szabó |author8=Árpád Mohácsi |author9=Gábor Szabó |author10=József Kaszaki |author11=Miklós Ghyczy |author12=Mihály Boros |title=Methane biogenesis during sodium azide-induced chemical hypoxia in rats|journal=American Journal of Physiology. Cell Physiology|date=15 January 2013|volume=304|issue=2|pages=207–214|doi=10.1152/ajpcell.00300.2012|pmid=23174561}}</ref>
Other authors have shown that cellular methane production also rises during [[sepsis]] or [[bacteria]]l [[endotoxemia]], including an experimental imitation of endotoxemia by lipopolysaccharide (LPS) administration.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Tuboly E, Szabó A, Erős G, Mohácsi A, Szabó G, Tengölics R, Rákhely G, Boros M |title=Determination of endogenous methane formation by photoacoustic spectroscopy.|journal=J Breath Res.|date=Dec 2013|volume=7|issue=4|doi=10.1088/1752-7155/7/4/046004|pmid=24185326|pages=046004|bibcode = 2013JBR.....7d6004T |url=http://publicatio.bibl.u-szeged.hu/4032/1/Tuboly_JBR_2013.pdf}}</ref>
Some other researchers have shown that methane, produced by the intestinal flora, is not fully "biologically neutral" to the intestine, and it participates in the normal physiologic regulation of [[peristalsis]]. And its excess causes not only belching, flatulence and belly pain, but also functional constipation.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Sahakian AB, Jee SR, Pimentel M |title=Methane and the gastrointestinal tract.|journal=Dig Dis Sci|date=Aug 2010|volume=55|issue=8|pages=2135–2143|doi=10.1007/s10620-009-1012-0|pmid=19830557}}</ref>
== Ethylene ==
[[File:Ethylene Signal Transduction.svg|thumb|An ethylene signal transduction pathway. Ethylene permeates the membrane and binds to a receptor on the endoplasmic reticulum. The receptor releases the repressed EIN2. This then activates a signal transduction pathway which activates a regulatory genes that eventually trigger an Ethylene response. The activated DNA is transcribed into mRNA which is then translated into a functional enzyme that is used for ethylene biosynthesis.]] Ethylene serves as a [[plant hormone|hormone]] in [[plant]]s.<ref name=Lin>{{cite journal |author1=Lin, Z. |author2=Zhong, S. |author3=Grierson, D. |title=Recent advances in ethylene research |journal=J. Exp. Bot. |volume=60 |pages=3311–36 |year=2009 |doi=10.1093/jxb/erp204 |issue=12 |pmid=19567479 }}</ref> It acts at trace levels throughout the life of the plant by stimulating or regulating the [[ripening]] of [[fruit]], the opening of [[flower]]s, and the [[abscission]] (or shedding) of [[Leaf|leaves]]. Commercial ripening rooms use "catalytic generators" to make ethylene gas from a liquid supply of ethanol. Typically, a gassing level of 500 to 2,000 ppm is used, for 24 to 48 hours. Care must be taken to control carbon dioxide levels in ripening rooms when gassing, as high temperature ripening ({{convert|20|C|F|disp=x|; }}){{citation needed|date=February 2014}} has been seen to produce CO<sub>2</sub> levels of 10% in 24 hours.<ref>[http://ne-postharvest.com/ripening.htm#controlledatmosphereripening External Link to More on Ethylene Gassing and Carbon Dioxide Control]. ne-postharvest.com</ref>
Ethylene has been used since the ancient Egyptians, who would gash figs in order to stimulate ripening (wounding stimulates ethylene production by plant tissues). The ancient Chinese would burn [[incense]] in closed rooms to enhance the ripening of pears. In 1864, it was discovered that gas leaks from street lights led to stunting of growth, twisting of plants, and abnormal thickening of stems.<ref name=Lin/> In 1901, a Russian scientist named Dimitry Neljubow showed that the active component was ethylene.<ref name="Neljobov_1901">{{cite journal | author = Neljubov D. | title = Uber die horizontale Nutation der Stengel von Pisum sativum und einiger anderen Pflanzen | journal = Beih Bot Zentralbl | volume = 10 | pages = 128–139 | year = 1901 }}</ref> Sarah Doubt discovered that ethylene stimulated [[abscission]] in 1917.<ref name="Doubt_1917">{{cite journal | author = Doubt, Sarah L.| title = The Response of Plants to Illuminating Gas | journal = Botanical Gazette | jstor= 2469142 | volume = 63 | issue = 3| pages = 209–224 | year = 1917 | doi = 10.1086/332006 }}</ref> It wasn't until 1934 that Gane reported that plants synthesize ethylene.<ref name="Gane_1934">{{cite journal | author = Gane R. | title = Production of ethylene by some fruits | journal = Nature| volume = 134| issue = 3400| pages = 1008| year = 1934 | doi = 10.1038/1341008a0 | bibcode = 1934Natur.134.1008G }}</ref> In 1935, Crocker proposed that ethylene was the plant hormone responsible for fruit ripening as well as [[senescence]] of vegetative tissues.<ref>Crocker W, Hitchcock AE, Zimmerman PW. (1935) "Similarities in the effects of ethlyene and the plant auxins". Contrib. Boyce Thompson Inst. 7. 231-48. Auxins Cytokinins IAA Growth substances, Ethylene</ref>
[[File:Yang-cycle.png|thumb|left|The Yang cycle]] Ethylene is produced from essentially all parts of higher plants, including leaves, stems, roots, flowers, fruits, tubers, and seeds. Ethylene production is regulated by a variety of developmental and environmental factors. During the life of the plant, ethylene production is induced during certain stages of growth such as [[germination]], [[ripening]] of fruits, [[abscission]] of leaves, and [[senescence]] of flowers. Ethylene production can also be induced by a variety of external aspects such as mechanical wounding, environmental stresses, and certain chemicals including auxin and other regulators.<ref name=Yang_1984>{{cite journal |author1=Yang, S. F. |author2=Hoffman N. E. | title = Ethylene biosynthesis and its regulation in higher plants | journal = Annu. Rev. Plant Physiol. | volume = 35 | pages = 155–89 | year = 1984 | doi = 10.1146/annurev.pp.35.060184.001103}}</ref>
Ethylene is [[biosynthesis|biosynthesized]] from the amino acid [[methionine]] to [[S-adenosyl methionine|''S''-adenosyl-<small>L</small>-methionine]] (SAM, also called Adomet) by the enzyme Met Adenosyltransferase. SAM is then converted to [[1-Aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylic acid|1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylic acid]] (ACC) by the enzyme [[1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylate synthase|ACC synthase]] (ACS). The activity of ACS determines the rate of ethylene production, therefore regulation of this [[enzyme]] is key for the ethylene biosynthesis. The final step requires oxygen and involves the action of the enzyme [[Aminocyclopropanecarboxylate oxidase|ACC-oxidase]] (ACO), formerly known as the ethylene forming enzyme (EFE). Ethylene biosynthesis can be induced by endogenous or exogenous ethylene. ACC synthesis increases with high levels of [[auxin]]s, especially [[indole acetic acid]] (IAA) and [[cytokinin]]s.
Ethylene is perceived by a family of five transmembrane [[protein dimer]]s such as the ETR<sub>1</sub> protein in ''Arabidopsis''. The [[gene]] [[encoding]] an ethylene receptor{{which|date=September 2013}} has been cloned in ''[[Arabidopsis thaliana]]'' and then in [[tomato]].{{citation needed|date=September 2013}} Ethylene receptors are encoded by multiple genes in the ''Arabidopsis'' and [[tomato]] [[genome]]s. Mutations in any of the [[gene family]], which comprises five receptors in ''Arabidopsis'' and at least six in tomato, can lead to insensitivity to ethylene.<ref>{{Cite journal | pmid = 9800203 | pmc = 1692356 | year = 1998 | author1 = Bleecker | first1 = A. B. | title = The ethylene-receptor family from Arabidopsis: Structure and function | journal = Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences | volume = 353 | issue = 1374 | pages = 1405–12 | last2 = Esch | first2 = J. J. | last3 = Hall | first3 = A. E. | last4 = Rodríguez | first4 = F. I. | last5 = Binder | first5 = B. M. | doi = 10.1098/rstb.1998.0295 }}</ref> [[DNA]] sequences for ethylene receptors have also been identified in many other plant species and an ethylene binding protein has even been identified in [[Cyanobacteria]].<ref name=Lin/>
Environmental cues such as flooding, drought, chilling, wounding, and pathogen attack can induce ethylene formation in plants. In flooding, roots suffer from lack of oxygen, or [[Hypoxia (environmental)|anoxia]], which leads to the synthesis of [[1-Aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylic acid|1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylic acid]] (ACC). ACC is transported upwards in the plant and then oxidized in leaves. The ethylene produced causes [[nastic movements]] (epinasty) of the leaves, perhaps helping the plant to lose water.<ref>[http://www.planthormones.info/epinasty.htm Explaining Epinasty]. planthormones.inf</ref>
Ethylene in plant induces such responses: * Seedling triple response, thickening and shortening of [[hypocotyl]] with pronounced apical hook. * In [[pollination]], when the pollen reaches the stigma, the precursor of the ethene, [[1-Aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylic acid|ACC]], is secreted to the petal, the ACC releases ethylene with ACC oxidase. * Stimulates leaf and flower [[senescence]] * Stimulates senescence of mature [[xylem]] cells in preparation for plant use * Induces leaf [[abscission]] * Induces seed [[germination]] * Induces [[root hair]] growth — increasing the efficiency of water and mineral absorption * Induces the growth of [[adventitious root]]s during flooding * Stimulates epinasty — leaf [[Petiole (botany)|petiole]] grows out, leaf hangs down and curls into itself * Stimulates [[fruit ripening]] * Induces a [[climacteric (botany)|climacteric]] rise in [[Cellular respiration|respiration]] in some fruit which causes a release of additional ethylene. * Affects [[gravitropism]] * Stimulates nutational bending * Inhibits stem growth and stimulates stem and cell broadening and lateral branch growth outside of seedling stage (see [[Hyponastic response]]) * Interference with [[auxin]] transport (with high [[auxin]] concentrations) * Inhibits shoot growth and [[stoma]]tal closing except in some water plants or habitually flooded ones such as some rice varieties, where the opposite occurs (conserving {{chem|CO|2}} and {{chem|O|2}}) * Induces flowering in [[pineapple]]s * Inhibits short day induced flower initiation in ''Pharbitus nil''<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors = Wilmowicz E, Kesy J, Kopcewicz J |title=Ethylene and ABA interactions in the regulation of flower induction in ''Pharbitis nil'' |journal=J. Plant Physiol. |volume=165 |issue=18 |pages=1917–28 |date=December 2008 |pmid=18565620 |doi=10.1016/j.jplph.2008.04.009 |url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0176-1617(08)00130-2}}</ref> and ''[[Chrysanthemum]] morifolium''<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Cockshull KE, Horridge JS |title=2-Chloroethylphosphonic Acid and Flower Initiation by ''Chrysanthemum morifolium'' Ramat. In Short Days and in Long Days |journal=Journal of Horticultural Science & Biotechnology |volume=53 |issue=2 |pages=85–90 |year=1978}}</ref>
Small amounts of endogenous ethylene are also produced in [[mammals]], including [[human]]s, due to lipid peroxidation. Some of endogenous ethylene is then oxidized to [[ethylene oxide]], which is able to [[alkylation|alkylate]] [[DNA]] and [[protein]]s, including [[hemoglobin]] (forming a specific adduct with its N-terminal [[valine]], N-hydroxyethyl-valine).<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors = Filser JG, Denk B, Törnqvist M, Kessler W, Ehrenberg L|title=Pharmacokinetics of ethylene in man; body burden with ethylene oxide and hydroxyethylation of hemoglobin due to endogenous and environmental ethylene.|journal=Arch Toxicol.|date=1992|volume=66|issue=3|pages=157–163|pmid=1303633|doi=10.1007/bf01974008}}</ref> Endogenous ethylene oxide, just as like environmental (exogenous) one, can alkylate [[guanine]] in DNA, forming an adduct 7-(2-hydroxyethyl)-guanine, and this poses an intrinsic carcinogenic risk.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors = Bolt HM, Leutbecher M, Golka K|title=A note on the physiological background of the ethylene oxide adduct 7-(2-hydroxyethyl)guanine in DNA from human blood.|journal=Arch Toxicol.|date=1997|volume=71|issue=11|pages=719–721|pmid=9363847|doi=10.1007/s002040050451}}</ref> It is also mutagenic.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors = Csanády GA, Denk B, Pütz C, Kreuzer PE, Kessler W, Baur C, Gargas ML, Filser JG|title=A physiological toxicokinetic model for exogenous and endogenous ethylene and ethylene oxide in rat, mouse, and human: formation of 2-hydroxyethyl adducts with hemoglobin and DNA.|journal=Toxicol Appl Pharmacol|date=May 15, 2000|volume=165|issue=1|pages=1–26|pmid=10814549|doi=10.1006/taap.2000.8918}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|vauthors = Thier R, Bolt HM|title=Carcinogenicity and genotoxicity of ethylene oxide: new aspects and recent advances.|journal=Crit Rev Toxicol.|date=Sep 2000|volume=30|issue=5|pages=595–608|pmid=11055837|doi=10.1080/10408440008951121}}</ref>
