[[Category:Photosynthesis]] [[Category:Lists of plants]]

<onlyinclude><!-- See [[Wikipedia_talk:Featured_lists#Proposed_change_to_all_featured_lists]] for an explanation of this and other inclusion tags below -->[[Image:Florida hurricane (pre-1900) tracks.jpg|right|thumb|320px|Tracks of hurricanes over [[Florida]] from 1851 to 1899]] The '''list of Florida hurricanes prior to 1900''' extends back to 1523 and encompasses 159 [[North Atlantic hurricane]]s known to have affected [[Florida]]. Since the start of the [[Atlantic hurricane reanalysis|Atlantic hurricane database]] in 1851, there were only eight years in which no tropical cyclone affected the state. Collectively, tropical cyclones in Florida resulted in at least 6,504 fatalities and monetary damage of over $90 million (2008 USD). At least 109 boats or ships were either driven ashore, wrecked, or damaged due to the storms.</onlyinclude>
Information is sparse for earlier years due to limitations in [[tropical cyclone observation]], though as coastlines became more populated, more data became available. The [[National Hurricane Center]] recognizes the uncertainty in both the death tolls and the dates of the events.<ref name="note">{{cite web|author1=Edward N. Rappaport |author2=Jose Fernandez-Partagas |lastauthoramp=yes|year=1995|title=Notes to the Appendices for the Deadliest Atlantic Tropical Cyclones, 1492-1996|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=2007-02-02|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/pastdeadlyappnote.shtml}}</ref> {{clear-right}} {{horizontal TOC|align=center|nonum=yes|limit=2}} <onlyinclude> ==Pre-1700== *1523 – Two ships and their crews are lost during a hurricane on the west Florida coast.<ref name="poss">{{cite web|author1=Edward N. Rappaport |author2=Jose Fernandez-Partagas |author3=Jack Beven |last-author-amp=yes |year=1997|title=The Deadliest Atlantic Tropical Cyclones, 1492-1996: Cyclones that may have caused 25+ deaths|publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]]|accessdate=2007-01-02|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/pastdeadlyapp2.shtml?}}</ref> *1553 – A hurricane affects the state, killing fewer than 700 people.<ref name="deadliest">{{cite web|author1=Edward N. Rappaport |author2=Jose Fernandez-Partagas |author3=Jack Beven |last-author-amp=yes |year=1997|title=The Deadliest Atlantic Tropical Cyclones, 1492-1996|publisher=[[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]]|accessdate=2007-01-02|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/pastdeadlyapp1.shtml?}}</ref> *Around 1553 – A hurricane hits western [[Florida]], resulting in about 700 casualties.<ref name="deadliest"/> Some modern researchers estimate this is the same storm as the previous event, as some early storms affecting more than one locale may have multiple listings if the storm track is unknown.<ref name="note"/> *1559 – A hurricane off northwestern Florida sinks six Spanish ships.<ref name="poss"/> *August 20, 1559 – Around 500 people are killed by a hurricane offshore at western Florida.<ref name="deadliest"/> *September 19, 1559 – A hurricane off the coast of Florida sinks several ships and kills many sailors.<ref name="poss"/> [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]] [[history of Pensacola, Florida|history]] notes this hurricane sinking 5 ships, with a [[Spain|Spanish]] [[galleon]], grounding a [[caravel]], and killing nearly 500 of 1,500 colonists and crewmen at ''Punta de Santa Maria'' across from [[Santa Rosa Island, Florida|Santa Rosa Island]]. *1563 – [[Cape Canaveral, Florida|Cape Canaveral]] experiences the effects of a hurricane, with 284 fatalities reported.<ref name="deadliest"/> *September 22, 1565 – An offshore hurricane washes several French ships ashore between [[Matanzas Inlet]] and [[Cape Canaveral, Florida|Cape Canaveral]], leaving 71 missing. The hurricane led to the loss of [[Fort Caroline]] and ultimately the [[French colonization of the Americas|French influence in Florida]].<ref name="poss"/><ref name="aoml">{{cite web|author1=Al Sandrik |author2=Chris Landsea |lastauthoramp=yes|year=2003|title=Chronological Listing of Tropical Cyclones affecting North Florida and Coastal Georgia 1565-1899|publisher=Hurricane Research Division|accessdate=2007-01-02|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/Landsea/history/index.html}}</ref> *September 13, 1566 – Rough seas and strong winds are experienced in the northeastern portion of the state by an offshore hurricane. It executes a loop and affects the area three days later.<ref name="aoml"/></onlyinclude> *September 26, 1566 – An offshore hurricane washes a ship ashore near [[Cape Canaveral, Florida|Cape Canaveral]].<ref name="aoml"/> *1571 – Two ships are lost on the Florida coastline during a hurricane, with few survivors.<ref name="poss"/> *Fall 1571 – A hurricane makes landfall near [[St. Augustine, Florida|Saint Augustine]], causing great damage to the city from strong winds and a powerful storm surge.<ref name="aoml"/> *1589 – One ship is wrecked during a hurricane along the eastern coast of the state.<ref name="poss"/> *1591 – 29 ships are lost along the coastal region of Florida during several tropical cyclones.<ref name="poss"/> *September 22, 1599 – A hurricane makes landfall a short distance south of [[St. Augustine, Florida|Saint Augustine]], destroying several houses and flooding the entire town.<ref name="aoml"/> *September 5, 1622 – 1,090 people are killed during a hurricane in the [[Straits of Florida]].<ref name="deadliest"/> *August 1638 – A hurricane strikes the northeastern portion of the state, though its effects, if any, are unknown.<ref name="aoml"/> *September 27, 1641 – After passing over the Florida Straits, a hurricane wrecks five ships. The storm produces tropical storm force winds and rough seas along the northeastern portion of the state.<ref name="aoml"/> *August 19, 1674 – A hurricane known as the '''Great Storm of 1674''' hits near [[St. Augustine, Florida|Saint Augustine]], and severely damages the town and its fort from rough seas.<ref name="aoml"/> *1683 – 496 people die from a hurricane that affects east-central Florida,<ref name="deadliest"/> though modern researchers question whether it was a hurricane or not.<ref name="note"/> *October 4, 1695 – A large ship is wrecked in the [[Florida Keys]] due to a passing hurricane.<ref name="poss"/>
==1700s== *September 30, 1707 – A hurricane makes landfall near or to the south of [[St. Augustine, Florida|Saint Augustine]]. Most of the houses in the town are destroyed due to the winds and storm surge. The storm drops rainfall there for at least 24 hours.<ref name="aoml"/> *Late June 1714 – Several ships are wrecked due to a hurricane in the [[Florida Keys]].<ref name="poss"/> *1715 – A hurricane sank 11 Spanish ships along a path from Ft. Pierce and south of Cape Canaveral carrying Gold and Silver; today this is known as the Treasure Coast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wreckoverysalvage.com/page11.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-01-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150225143622/http://www.wreckoverysalvage.com/page11.html |archivedate=2015-02-25 |df= }}</ref> *July 15, 1733 – A hurricane passes through [[The Bahamas]] and southern [[Florida]], killing a total of 56 people.<ref name="deadliest"/> *1741 – A storm hits northwest Florida at [[Santa Rosa Island, Florida|Santa Rosa Island]].<ref name="uwf">{{cite web|author=University of West Florida |year=2004 |title=Overview and History of Presidio Isla de Santa Rosa |accessdate=2007-01-09 |url=http://www.uwf.edu/anthropology/research/SantaRosa.cfm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070319030901/http://uwf.edu/anthropology/research/SantaRosa.cfm |archivedate=2007-03-19 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *1752 – A large storm hits northwest Florida at [[Santa Rosa Island, Florida|Santa Rosa Island]], at ''Presidio Isla de Santa Rosa'', destroying all but 2 buildings.<ref name="uwf"/> *October 22, 1752 – Multiple vessels are lost during a hurricane off the state.<ref name="poss"/> *August 24, 1753 – A tropical storm passing through the northeastern portion of the state drops heavy precipitation.<ref name="aoml"/> *1758 – A hurricane which strikes [[St. Marks, Florida|St. Marks]] results in 40 fatalities.<ref name="deadliest"/> *October 23, 1766 – A ship capsizes due to a hurricane off northwestern Florida.<ref name="poss"/> *September 25, 1769 – Northeastern Florida experiences strong winds from a hurricane, though it is unknown if it makes landfall or not.<ref name="aoml"/> *October 29, 1769 – A strong hurricane hits [[Miami, Florida|Miami]], blowing down several trees and grounding a ship.<ref name="aoml"/> *June 1777 – A ship is lost off Florida, with the entire crew missing and believed killed.<ref name="poss"/> *October 14, 1780 – A storm, possibly related to the [[Great Hurricane of 1780]], impacts the northeastern portion of the state with moderate winds and severe beach erosion.<ref name="aoml"/> *1781 – About 2,000 people are killed due to a hurricane off the coast of the state.<ref name="deadliest"/> *Early October 1794 – A hurricane estimated to have moved inland from the southwestern portion of the state resulted in moderate beach erosion near [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]].<ref name="aoml"/> *October 17, 1797 – An offshore hurricane capsizes a few ships off the eastern coast of Florida.<ref name="aoml"/>
==1800–1849== *September 7, 1804 – An [[1804 Antigua–Charleston hurricane|offshore hurricane]] sinks eight ships in the harbor of [[St. Augustine, Florida|Saint Augustine]] and destroys the Quasada Battery at the mouth of the [[St. Johns River]] from its storm surge.<ref name="aoml"/> *September 15, 1806 – Saint Augustine receives a landfall from a severe hurricane that destroys several houses, uproots many trees, washes several vessels ashore, and destroys the city pier.<ref name="aoml"/> *October 4, 1811 – A hurricane of moderate intensity strikes near [[St. Augustine, Florida|Saint Augustine]], with many houses in the city damaged or destroyed. Shipwrecks were reported throughout the eastern Florida coastline.<ref name="sandrick11">{{cite web|author=Sandrick|year=1999|title=Effects of October 4, 1811 hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-06|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1811/storm2_other.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> Several destroyed homes are not rebuilt for 11 years.<ref name="aoml"/> *October 1, 1812 – A hurricane remains stationary offshore of northeastern Florida, producing severe conditions along portions of the [[St. Johns River]].<ref name="aoml"/> *September 16, 1813 – The [[eye (cyclone)|eye]] of a major hurricane passes over the border between Florida and [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]].<ref name="aoml"/> *August 7, 1817 – A tropical storm hits near [[Apalachicola Bay]], though its effects are unknown.<ref name="aoml"/> *September 1819 – Heavy rainfall is caused by a tropical storm making landfall between [[New Orleans, Louisiana|New Orleans]] and [[Apalachicola, Florida|Apalachicola]].<ref name="barnes19">{{cite web|author=Barnes|year=1998|title=Effects of September 1819 storm|accessdate=2007-01-06|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1819/storm2_barnes.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *September 15, 1821 – A hurricane estimated to have made landfall near the border of [[Alabama]] and [[Mississippi]] produces high tides along the [[Florida Panhandle]], sinking six ships in [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]] and causing minor damage to homes.<ref name="ludlum21">{{cite web|author=Ludlum|title=Effects of September 15, 1821 hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-06|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1821/storm2_ludlum.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *July 8, 1822 – A ship is breached along the extreme western [[Florida Panhandle]] as a result of a tropical storm striking [[Mississippi]].<ref name="ludlum22">{{cite web|author=Ludlum|year=1963|title=Effects of July 8, 1822 Tropical Storm|accessdate=2007-01-06|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1822/storm1_ludlum.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *September 14, 1824 – A storm which moves inland near [[Darien, Georgia]] brings hurricane force conditions to northeastern Florida.<ref name="aoml"/> *June 2, 1825 – An early season storm produces gusty and rainy conditions in northeastern Florida after hitting between [[Cedar Key, Florida|Cedar Key]] and [[Apalachicola, Florida|Apalachicola]].<ref name="aoml"/> *October 2, 1825 – [[St. Augustine, Florida|Saint Augustine]] is struck by a minimal hurricane. The hurricane produces a 4 foot [[storm surge]], causing some damage to houses, while moderate winds wash four ships aground and damage orange crops.<ref name="sandrick25">{{cite web|author=Sandrick|year=1999|title=Effects of October 2, 1825 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-06|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1825/storm2_other.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *August 15, 1830 – A hurricane which ultimately moves inland on [[South Carolina]] parallels the eastern coast of the state, bringing strong winds and rain to coastal areas.<ref name="ludlum30">{{cite web|author=Ludlum|title=Effects of August 15, 1830 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-06|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1830/storm1_pt1_ludlum.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *August 22, 1830 – Just days after the previous storm, another hurricane impacts and parallels the eastern coastline.<ref name="barnes30">{{cite web|author=Barnes|year=1998|title=Effects of August 22, 1830 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-06|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1830/storm2_pt1_barnes.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *June 10, 1831 – A tropical storm which struck the [[Florida Panhandle]] brings strong winds to [[St. Augustine, Florida|Saint Augustine]].<ref name="aoml"/> *Early August 1835 – An offshore tropical storm produces winds in excess of 40 mph (65 km/h) in the northeastern portion of the state.<ref name="aoml"/> *August 15, 1835 – [[Key West, Florida|Key West]] and the [[Dry Tortugas]] report gusty winds from a hurricane passing through central [[Cuba]].<ref name="ludlum35">{{cite web|author=Ludlum|title=Effects of August 15, 1835 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-06|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1835/storm1_ludlum.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *September 14, 1835 – A major hurricane strikes southeastern Florida, moves across the state, and recurves in the [[Gulf of Mexico]] before hitting near [[Tampa Bay]]. In the southeastern portion of the state, the hurricane severely floods several islands, while damage in and around Tampa totals $200,000 (1835 [[United States dollar|USD]], $4.1 million 2008 USD). After moving northeastward through the state, the hurricane destroys the lighthouse at the [[Ponce de León Inlet]].<ref name="barnes35">{{cite web|author=Barnes|year=1998|title=Effects of September 14, 1835 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-07|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1835/storm2_barnes.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *August 1, 1837 – East-central Florida is struck by a minimal hurricane which produces heavy rainfall and strong winds for northeastern Florida.<ref name="ludlum37">{{cite web|author=Ludlum|title=Effects of August 1, 1837 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-06|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1837/storm1_ludlum.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *August 7, 1837 – A storm estimated to have struck [[Mississippi]] destroys several warehouses in [[St. Marks, Florida|Saint Marks]] from its 6 foot (1.8 m) storm surge.<ref name="ludlum37a">{{cite web|author=Ludlum|title=Effects of August 7, 1837 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-06|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1837/storm2_ludlum.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *August 7, 1837 – Simultaneously existing with the previous storm, a hurricane moves ashore near [[Fernandina Beach, Florida|Fernandina Beach]], destroying at least nineteen buildings from moderate winds and higher than usual tides.<ref name="ludlum37b">{{cite web|author=Ludlum|title=Effects of August 7, 1837 Hurricane (2)|accessdate=2007-01-06|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1837/storm3_ludlum.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *August 16, 1837 – A storm known as the '''Calypso Hurricane''' parallels the eastern coastline offshore and produces tropical storm force winds in the northeastern portion of the state.<ref name="aoml"/> *Mid-August 1837 – A hurricane makes landfall south of [[St. Augustine, Florida|Saint Augustine]] and after moving northwestward through the state it passes through [[Tallahassee, Florida|Tallahassee]].<ref name="barnes37">{{cite web|author=Barnes|year=1998|title=Effects of Mid-August, 1837 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-06|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1837/storm5_barnes.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *August 30, 1837 – A small storm estimated to have been a major hurricane strikes the northwestern Florida coastline. Considered by some to be the most severe gale in the area, the hurricane produces tides estimated at 15 feet (4.6 m) above normal. Flooding from the storm damages or destroys multiple buildings, causing eight deaths and $230,000 in damage (1837 USD, $4.4 million 2008 USD).<ref name="ludlum37c">{{cite web|author=Ludlum|title=Effects of August 30, 1837 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-06|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1837/storm6_ludlum.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *September 13, 1837 – [[St. Augustine, Florida|Saint Augustine]] reports moderate northeasterly winds from a nearby hurricane, though other details are unknown.<ref name="ludlum37d">{{cite web|author=Ludlum|title=Effects of September 13, 1837 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-06|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1837/storm7_ludlum.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *September 24, 1837 – A tropical storm believed to have struck the east-central coastline produces moderate winds in northeastern Florida.<ref name="aoml"/> *October 7, 1837 – The [[1837 Racer's Storm|Racer's Storm]] moves inland to the west of the state, causing moderate damage along the [[Florida Panhandle]].<ref name="ludlum37e">{{cite web|author=Ludlum|title=Effects of Racer's Storm|accessdate=2007-01-06|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1837/storm9_pt2_ludlum.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *September 7, 1838 – A hurricane strikes near [[Key Biscayne]], killing 38 people.<ref name="deadliest"/> *September 14, 1841 – The town of [[St. Joseph, Gulf County, Florida|St. Joseph]] is destroyed by a hurricane hitting the [[Florida Panhandle]].<ref name="barnes41">{{cite web|author=Barnes|year=1998|title=Effects of September 14, 1841 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-06|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1841/storm1_barnes.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *October 18, 1841 – A northeastward moving hurricane passes south of the [[Florida Keys]] and wash many ships aground.<ref name="barnes41a">{{Cite web|author=Barnes|year=1998|title=Effects of October 18, 1841 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-06|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1841/storm3_barnes.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *August 2, 1842 – A weak tropical storm produces heavy rainfall in northeastern Florida.<ref name="aoml"/> *September 4, 1842 – Moderate damage is caused by a hurricane passing [[Key West, Florida|Key West]].<ref name="ludlum42">{{cite web|author=Ludlum|title=Effects of September 4, 1842 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-06|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1842/storm4_ludlum.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *September 22, 1842 – A tropical storm makes landfall near [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]].<ref name="barnes42b">{{Cite web|author=Barnes|year=1998|title=Effects of September 22, 1842 Storm|accessdate=2007-01-06|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1842/storm6_barnes.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *October 4, 1842 – A 955 [[Bar (unit)|mbar]] major hurricane which makes landfall on northwestern Florida produces a 20 foot (6 m) storm surge at [[Cedar Key, Florida|Cedar Key]]. Strong winds result in severe damage in [[Tallahassee, Florida|Tallahassee]], where damage amounts to $500,000 (1842 USD, $11.1 million 2008 USD). [[St. Augustine, Florida|Saint Augustine]] reports strong winds and heavy rainfall.<ref name="ludlum1042">{{cite web|author=Ludlum|title=Effects of October 4, 1842 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-06|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1842/storm7_ludlum.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *October 26, 1842 – An offshore storm produces tropical storm force winds and high tides.<ref name="aoml"/> *September 13, 1843 – [[Port Leon, Florida|Port Leon]] is struck by a strong hurricane and is nearly destroyed by its 10 foot (3 m) [[storm surge]].<ref name="ludlum43">{{cite web|author=Ludlum|title=Effects of September 13, 1843 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-11|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1843/storm1_ludlum.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> Residents in the city moved four miles northward in response to the hurricane and formed the city of [[Newport, Wakulla County, Florida|Newport]].<ref name="barnes43">{{cite web|author=Barnes|year=1998|title=Effects of September 13, 1843 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-11|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1843/storm1_barnes.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> The hurricane kills 14 in the [[Florida Panhandle]],<ref name="ludlum43"/> of which only one occurred in Port Leon.<ref name="barnes43"/> *September 7, 1844 – A small, intense hurricane hits near [[Daytona Beach, Florida|Daytona Beach]], and is considered by one modern historian to be the most severe storm to affect northeastern Florida in the 19th century. After crossing the state, the [[eye (cyclone)|eye]] passed over [[Apalachicola, Florida|Apalachicola]]<ref name="aoml"/> where its strong winds destroyed the roofs of several buildings.<ref name="barnes44">{{cite web|author=Barnes|title=Effects of September 8, 1844 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-11|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1844/storm3_barnes.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *October 4, 1844 – A large hurricane passes through the [[Straits of Florida|Florida Straits]] and produces high tides and strong winds along the eastern coastline.<ref name="ludlum44">{{cite web|author=Ludlum|title=Effects of October 4, 1844 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-11|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1844/storm4_pt2_ludlum.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *October 11, 1846 – The [[Great Havana Hurricane of 1846]] passes near [[Key West, Florida|Key West]] with an estimated pressure of 902 [[Bar (unit)|mbar]] (hPa) and winds of possibly [[List of Category 5 Atlantic hurricanes|Category 5 status]],<ref name="ho46">{{cite web|author=Ho|title=Effects of October 11, 1846 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-11|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1846/storm2_pt1_ho.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> damaging or destroying all but 6 of the houses in the city. 50 are killed,<ref name="barnes46">{{cite web|author=Barnes|year=1998|title=Effects of October 11, 1846 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-11|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1846/storm2_pt1_barnes.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> and damage amounts to $200,000 (1846 USD, $4.8 million 2008 USD). It is estimated it struck mainland Florida near [[Cedar Key, Florida|Cedar Key]],<ref name="ludlum46">{{cite web|author=Ludlum|title=Effects of October 11, 1846 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-11|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1846/storm2_pt1_barnes.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> producing severe flooding and strong winds.<ref name="aoml"/> *September 25, 1848 – The [[Great Gale of 1848]] strikes near [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]] as a major hurricane with an estimated pressure of 948 [[Bar (unit)|mbar]].<ref name="aoml"/> Considered one of the most significant hurricanes in the Tampa area, the 15 foot (4.6 m) storm surge from the hurricane destroyed much of Tampa and nearby [[Fort Brooke]].<ref name="barnes48">{{cite web|author=Barnes|year=1998|title=Effects of September 25, 1848 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-11|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1848/storm2_barnes.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *October 11, 1848 – A major hurricane hits northwestern Florida, causing additional damage to the severe hurricane a few weeks before.<ref name="barnes48a">{{cite web|author=Barnes|year=1998|title=Effects of October 11, 1848 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-11|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1848/storm3_barnes.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref>
==1850–1859== *August 23, 1850 – A large hurricane strikes near [[Apalachicola, Florida|Apalachicola]], with its powerful storm surge destroying many ships and flooding coastal roads.<ref name="barnes50">{{cite web|author=Barnes|year=1998|title=Effects of August 23, 1850 Hurricane|accessdate=2007-01-11|url=http://myweb.fsu.edu/jelsner/temp/HHITProject/HHITyears/1850/storm2_pt1_barnes.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *August 24, 1851 – [[Apalachicola, Florida|Apalachicola]] is hit by a major hurricane, causing severe damage in the [[St. Marks, Florida|St. Marks]] area from its 12 foot (3.7 m) [[storm surge|storm tide]].<ref name="meta">{{cite web|author1=Chris Landsea |author2=Craig Anderson |author3=Noel Charles |author4=Gil Clark |author5=Jason Dunion |author6=Charlie Neumann |author7=Mark Zimmer |author8=Jose Fernandez-Partagas |author9=William Bredemeyer |author10=John Gamache |author11=Lenworth Woolcock |last-author-amp=yes |year=2006 |title=Documentation of Atlantic Tropical Cyclones Changes in HURDAT |publisher=NOAA |accessdate=2007-01-12 |url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/metadata_master.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604063810/http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/metadata_master.html |archivedate=2011-06-04 |df= }}</ref> *August 22, 1852 – The first hurricane of the season produces hurricane-force winds in the [[Florida Keys]].<ref name="meta"/> It later makes landfall near the [[Mississippi]]/[[Alabama]] border, producing strong winds and a pressure of 980 [[Bar (unit)|mbar]] in [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]].<ref name="52h1">{{cite web|author=Hurricane Research Division|year=2004|title=Observations for Hurricane 2 in 1852|accessdate=2007-01-12|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/excelfiles_centerfix/1852_1.xls|format=XLS|publisher=NOAA}}</ref> *September 12, 1852 – The third hurricane of the season strikes near [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]], producing strong winds and high seas in coastal areas.<ref name="aoml"/> Rainfall from the storm totals 0.55 inches (14 mm) at [[Fort Meade, Florida|Fort Meade]].<ref name="meta"/> *October 9, 1852 – [[St. Marks, Florida|St. Marks]] is hit by a moderate hurricane which results in downed trees and damage to multiple small structures.<ref name="aoml"/> *October 20, 1853 – A storm paralleling the northeastern Florida coastline produces hurricane-force winds and coastal flooding.<ref name="aoml"/> *September 8, 1854 – The third hurricane of the season parallels the northeastern Florida coastline as a major hurricane before striking eastern [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]. Though it is very severe offshore, impact is minor in Florida.<ref name="aoml"/> *August 31, 1856 – A [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 2 hurricane]] hits near [[Panama City, Florida|Panama City]], producing a pressure of 968 [[Bar (unit)|mbar]] and a storm tide of 6 feet (1.8 m) at [[Apalachicola, Florida|Apalachicola]].<ref name="meta"/> *September 15, 1858 – The third tropical storm of the season hits near [[Tampa Bay]] and causes little effects as it crosses the state.<ref name="aoml"/> *September 16, 1859 – A hurricane hits southern [[Alabama]] and produces hurricane force conditions in western Florida. The storm produces heavy rainfall including a total of 3.3 inches (84 mm) in Barrancas Barracks, and destroys several buildings near the coast at [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]]. One ship is washed aground.<ref name="meta"/> *October 17, 1859 – A tropical storm hits near [[Fort Lauderdale, Florida|Fort Lauderdale]], though effects, if any, are unknown.{{hurdat}}
==1860–1869== *August 16, 1861 – The second hurricane of the season passes a short distance to the west of the [[Florida Keys]], producing 35 mph (56 km/h) winds at [[Dry Tortugas National Park|Fort Jefferson]].<ref name="61h2">{{cite web|author=Hurricane Research Division|year=2004|title=Observations for Hurricane 2 in 1861|accessdate=2007-01-12|publisher=NOAA|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/excelfiles_centerfix/1861_2.xls|format=XLS}}</ref> The storm is believed to have later turned to the northeast, cross over the state, and wash a [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]] ship ashore at [[St. Augustine, Florida|Saint Augustine]].<ref name="aoml"/> *November 1, 1861 – A tropical storm hits near [[Chokoloskee, Florida|Chokoloskee]] on the southwest coastline, crosses the state, and exits into the [[Atlantic Ocean]] near [[Cape Canaveral, Florida|Cape Canaveral]]. Impact, if any, is unknown.{{hurdat}} *May 28, 1863 – Strong hurricane "Amanda" struck northwest Florida on May 28; the earliest landfall during a year known in the US.<ref>{{cite journal |last = Chenoweth |first = M. |author2=C.J. Mock |title = Hurricane "Amanda": Rediscovery of a Forgotten U.S. Civil War Florida Hurricane |journal = Bull. Am. Meteorol. Soc. |volume = 94 |issue = 11 |pages = 1735–42 |date = 2013 |doi = 10.1175/BAMS-D-12-00171.1 |bibcode = 2013BAMS...94.1735C }}</ref> *September 17, 1863 – An offshore tropical storm causes disruption in shipping in the coastal waters off eastern Florida.<ref name="aoml"/> *October 23, 1865 – The final hurricane of the season passes through the western [[Florida Keys]] and hits near [[Cape Sable]], producing heavy rainfall of 4.1 inches (104 mm) in [[Key West, Florida|Key West]] and strong winds throughout the state.<ref name="meta"/> *October 6, 1867 – A hurricane hits near the mouth of the [[Steinhatchee River]], though effects, if any, are unknown.{{hurdat}} *October 4, 1868 – [[Apalachicola, Florida|Apalachicola]] is struck by a tropical storm. There were no reports of damage.{{hurdat}}
==1870–1879== *October 9, 1870 – A [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 2 hurricane]] moves northeastward through the [[Florida Straits]], producing hurricane-force winds across the southern portion of the state. Impact is unknown in the state.<ref name="meta"/> *October 20, 1870 – The [[eye (cyclone)|eye]] of a moderate hurricane passes over the [[Dry Tortugas]], producing heavy rainfall and widespread debris. It later strikes [[Chokoloskee, Florida|Chokoloskee]], crosses the state, and tracks out to sea.<ref name="meta"/> Numerous fatalities were reported in the state.<ref name="deadliest"/> *August 17, 1871 – A major hurricane makes landfall near [[Palm Beach, Florida|Palm Beach]] with a pressure of 952 [[Bar (unit)|mbar]].<ref name="meta"/> The hurricane causes several shipwrecks on the Atlantic coastline, while in [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]] moderate winds destroy the roofs of several weak buildings.<ref name="aoml"/> *August 25, 1871 – The fourth tropical storm and second hurricane of the season hits near [[Palm Beach, Florida|Palm Beach]], causing at least one shipwreck along the coastline.<ref name="aoml"/> *September 6, 1871 – A minor hurricane hits near the mouth of the [[Steinhatchee River]] and produces heavy rainfall across the state.<ref name="aoml"/> *October 5, 1871 – [[St. Marks, Florida|Saint Marks]] is struck by a tropical storm, though its effects, if any, are unknown.{{hurdat}} *October 23, 1872 – A tropical storm hits near [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]] and produces 5.94 inches (151 mm) of rainfall in [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]].<ref name="aoml"/> *June 2, 1873 – The first storm of the season hits near the Florida/[[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] border and produces light winds, including a report of 28 mph (45 km/h) in [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]].<ref name="aoml"/> *September 19, 1873 – A hurricane hits near [[St. Marks, Florida|Saint Marks]] and causes heavy damage in [[Tallahassee, Florida|Tallahassee]].<ref name="meta"/> *September 23, 1873 – [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]] is struck by a tropical storm. Its impact is unknown.{{hurdat}} *October 7, 1873 – A major hurricane makes landfall near [[Fort Myers, Florida|Fort Myers]] and causes heavy damage in [[Punta Rassa, Florida|Punta Rassa]] from its 14 foot (4.3 m) [[storm surge|storm tide]].<ref name="meta"/> *September 28, 1874 – The sixth storm and third hurricane of the season hits near [[Yankeetown, Florida|Yankeetown]] and, after briefly being downgraded to a tropical storm, exits later that day near the Florida-[[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] state line. Impact is unknown.{{hurdat}} *September 14, 1875 – [[Key West, Florida|Key West]] reports 45 mph (72 km/h) winds in association with a hurricane that passes to the southwest of the state.<ref name="75h03">{{cite web|author=Hurricane Research Division|year=2004|title=Observations for Hurricane 3 in 1875|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2007-01-14|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/excelfiles_centerfix/1875_3.xls|format=XLS}}</ref> *September 27, 1875 – A tropical storm hits near [[Panama City, Florida|Panama City]] before quickly dissipating. Its effects are unknown.<ref name="meta"/> *September 16, 1876 – [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]] experiences 22 mph (35 km/h) from a tropical storm paralleling the east coast of Florida.<ref name="aoml"/> *October 20, 1876 – A moderate hurricane passes near [[Key West, Florida|Key West]] and later strikes near [[Cape Sable]], though its impact, if any, is unknown.{{hurdat}} *September 19, 1877 – After hitting southern [[Louisiana]], a hurricane makes landfall near [[Panama City, Florida|Panama City]], though its effects, if any, are unknown.{{hurdat}} *October 3, 1877 – The third hurricane of the season strikes near [[Apalachicola, Florida|Apalachicola]] as a [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|major hurricane]], producing a [[storm surge|storm tide]] of 12 feet (3.7 m) and a pressure of 988 [[Bar (unit)|mbar]] at [[St. Marks, Florida|Saint Marks]].<ref name="meta"/> Damage, if any, is unknown. *October 26, 1877 – A tropical storm hits near [[Cedar Key, Florida|Cedar Key]], causing no known damage.<ref name="aoml"/> *July 2, 1878 – The first storm of the season moves onshore just south of [[Fort Myers, Florida|Fort Myers]], though its effects are unknown.{{hurdat}} *September 8, 1878 – A tropical storm hits near [[Key Largo]], moves northwestward, and strengthens in the [[Gulf of Mexico]] before looping to the northeast and striking near [[Yankeetown, Florida|Yankeetown]] as a [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 2]] hurricane.{{hurdat}} Rainfall reaches 4.93 inches (155 mm) in [[Key West, Florida|Key West]],<ref name="1878mwr">{{cite web|author=Office of the Chief Signal Officer of the United States Department|year=1878|title=1878 Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1878.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> and in [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]] the storm produces a pressure of 989 [[Bar (unit)|mbar]] and winds of up to 48 mph (77 km/h). There, high tides result in flooding near waterways.<ref name="aoml"/> At least one death was reported in the state.<ref name="poss"/> *October 10, 1878 – Heavy amounts of precipitation is caused by a tropical storm making landfall near [[Apalachicola, Florida|Apalachacola]].<ref name="1878mwr"/> *October 21, 1878 – [[Gale of 1878|A hurricane]] paralleling the east coast of Florida produces winds in excess of 75 mph (120 km/h) along the coastline and rainfall peaking at 4.8 inches (122 mm) at [[Key West, Florida|Key West]]. Over a dozen ships are driven aground.<ref name="galeof78">{{cite web|author1=David Roth |author2=Hugh Cobb |lastauthoramp=yes|year=2000|title=Gale of '78|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/research/roth/galeof78.htm}}</ref> *October 16, 1879 – [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]] is struck by a weak tropical storm which produces light winds and moderate rainfall peaking at 2.36 inches (60 mm) in [[St. Marks, Florida|Saint Marks]].<ref name="1879mwr">{{cite web|author=Office of the Chief Signal Officer of the United States Department|year=1879|title=1879 Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1879.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *October 27, 1879 – A tropical storm hits near [[Cedar Key, Florida|Cedar Key]], producing gusty winds in [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]] but causing no known damage.<ref name="aoml"/>
==1880–1889== *August 29, 1880 – 68 people die from a shipwreck as a result of a [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 2]] hurricane making landfall just to the south of [[Cocoa Beach, Florida]].{{Atlantic hurricane best track}} Several other ships are washed ashore from [[Jupiter, Florida|Jupiter Inlet]] to the mouth of the [[St. Johns River]], and another is damaged in the [[Gulf of Mexico]] after the hurricane crosses the state. In [[Cedar Key, Florida|Cedar Key]] it is considered one of the worst hurricanes on record, with several buildings destroyed.<ref name="1880mwr">{{cite web|author=Office of the Chief Signal Officer of the United States Department|year=1880|title=1880 Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1880.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *September 8, 1880 – A tropical storm hits near [[Yankeetown, Florida|Yankeetown]], producing light amounts of rain and wind across the northern portion of the state.<ref name="aoml"/> *October 8, 1880 – The ninth storm and eighth hurricane of the season moves ashore just south of Yankeetown, though its impact, if any, is unknown.{{hurdat}} *August 1, 1881 – [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]] reports 15.95 inches (405 mm) of rainfall in association with a tropical storm that hits near the [[Alabama]]/[[Mississippi]] border.<ref name="1881mwr">{{cite web|author=Office of the Chief Signal Officer of the United States Department|year=1881|title=1881 Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1881.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *August 17, 1881 – A northeastward moving tropical storm passes just south of the [[Florida Keys]] and produces heavy rainfall and winds peaking at 28 mph (45 km/h) in Punta Russa.<ref name="1881mwr"/> *August 28, 1881 – [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]] experiences light winds from a hurricane that strikes [[Savannah, Georgia]].<ref name="aoml"/> *September 10, 1882 – The second hurricane of the season makes landfall as a major hurricane at [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]], where it was considered to be among the most severe on record. Several boats are washed ashore along the Gulf of Mexico coastline. In and around [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]], the strong winds greatly damage the cotton crop and destroy several buildings, killing five people.<ref name="1882mwr">{{cite web|year=1882|title=Monthly Weather Review|publisher=United States Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1882.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *October 11, 1882 – A minimal hurricane hits near [[Yankeetown, Florida|Yankeetown]], causing moderate coastal flooding and heavy rainfall.<ref name="1882mwr"/> *September 10, 1883 – [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]] reports heavy rainfall in intervals and moderate winds from a hurricane paralleling the eastern coastline.<ref name="1883mwr">{{cite web|year=1883|title=Monthly Weather Review|publisher=United States Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1883.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *September 10, 1884 – An offshore tropical storm which later becomes a hurricane produces higher than normal tides in northeastern Florida.<ref name="aoml"/> *August 24, 1885 – Light rainfall and gale force winds is reported in [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]] in association with a hurricane paralleling the eastern coastline.<ref name="1885mwr">{{cite web|year=1885|title=Monthly Weather Review|publisher=United States Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1885.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *August 30, September 21, and September 30, 1885 – Three tropical storms affect western Florida. Winds were not exceptionally strong, though the passage of the three storms contribute to a wet month in some portions of northern Florida, with precipitation accumulating to around 20 inches (500 mm) of rain.<ref name="aoml"/> *October 11, 1885 – The eighth storm of the season hits near the mouth of the [[Steinhatchee River]], producing localized street flooding and moderate winds.<ref name="aoml"/> *June 21, 1886 – An unusual [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 2]] hurricane in the month of June strikes near [[St. Marks, Florida|St. Marks]], producing strong winds gusts but little damage.<ref name="1886mwr">{{cite web|year=1886|title=Monthly Weather Review|publisher=United States Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1886.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *June 30, 1886 – A week after the previous storm, another Category 2 hurricane hits the central [[Florida Panhandle]], causing damage to numerous ships and capsizing several others. The winds of the hurricane destroy dozens of houses and buildings, killing several people.<ref name="1886mwr"/> *July 19, 1886 – The fourth storm of the season makes landfall near [[Yankeetown, Florida|Yankeetown]] and produces gusty winds yet little damage.<ref name="1886mwr"/> *August 18, 1886 – The [[Indianola Hurricane of 1886|Indianola Hurricane]] passes just south of the [[Florida Keys]], with [[Key West, Florida|Key West]] reporting a peak gust of 52 mph (84 km/h).<ref name="86h05">{{cite web|author=Hurricane Research Division|year=2004|title=Observations for Hurricane Five in 1886|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/excelfiles_centerfix/1886/STORM5.XLS|format=XLS}}</ref> *July 27, 1887 – A hurricane hits near [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]] and produces heavy rainfall peaking at 8 inches (203 mm) in [[Cedar Key, Florida|Cedar Key]]. The rainfall, in combination with strong winds and rough seas, cause heavy damage to crops and roads.<ref name="1887mwr">{{cite web|year=1887|title=Monthly Weather Review|publisher=United States Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1887.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *August 22, 1887 – A major hurricane paralleling the eastern coastline produces strong winds near the coast.<ref name="1887mwr"/> *October 20, 1887 – Heavy rainfall is reported in association with a hurricane crossing the northwestern [[Florida Panhandle]].<ref name="1887mwr"/> *October 30, 1887 – The sixteenth storm of the season hits near [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]], though its effects, if any, are unknown.{{hurdat}} *August 16, 1888 – A major hurricane moves ashore on southeastern Florida, producing 2.02 inches (51 mm) of precipitation at [[Jupiter, Florida|Jupiter]] and a storm tide of 14 feet (4.3 m) at [[Miami, Florida|Miami]]. Damage is unknown.<ref name="meta"/><ref name="1888mwr">{{cite web|year=1888|title=Monthly Weather Review|publisher=United States Weather Bureau|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1888.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *September 7, 1888 – 2.48 inches (63 mm) of rain is recorded in [[Fort Meade, Florida|Fort Meade]] in association with a tropical storm striking near [[Palm Beach, Florida|Palm Beach]].<ref name="88ts05">{{cite web|author=Hurricane Research Division|year=2004|title=Observations for Tropical Storm Five in 1888|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/excelfiles_centerfix/1888/STORM5.XLS|format=XLS}}</ref> *September 23, 1888 – The sixth storm of the season formed just south of the [[Florida Keys]] before briefly moving onshore in the extreme southeastern portion of the state. Effects, if any, are unknown.{{hurdat}} *October 11, 1888 – A [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 2]] hurricane hits near [[Yankeetown, Florida|Yankeetown]]. It produces high tides and moderate winds, and destroys a hotel on [[Fort George Island Cultural State Park|Fort George Island]].<ref name="aoml"/> *June 17, 1889 – The second storm of the season moves ashore near [[Yankeetown, Florida|Yankeetown]]. Impact, if any, is unknown.{{hurdat}} *September 23, 1889 – After weakening from hurricane status, a tropical storm makes landfall on [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]], though its effects, if any, are unknown.{{hurdat}} *October 6, 1889 – The final storm of the season strikes extreme southern Florida after passing through the Florida Keys, causing no known effects.{{hurdat}}
==1890–1899== *August 24, 1891 – A minimal hurricane hits near [[Homestead, Florida|Homestead]], though due to lack of observations near the landfall location its impact in the state is unknown.<ref name="meta"/> *October 7, 1891 – The seventh storm of the season strikes [[Cape Sable]] and causes no known impact.{{hurdat}} *October 9, 1891 – Shortly after becoming an [[extratropical cyclone]], a storm crosses the state from [[Fort Myers, Florida|Fort Myers]] to [[Cape Canaveral, Florida|Cape Canaveral]], producing light winds across the state.<ref name="aoml"/> *June 10, 1892 – A tropical storm which makes landfall near [[Cape Sable, Florida|Cape Sable]] drops large amounts of precipitation across the southern Florida.<ref name="1892mwr">{{cite web|author=United States Weather Bureau|year=1892|title=Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1892.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *September 12, 1892 – Southeastern [[Louisiana]] is hit by a tropical storm, with winds in [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]] reaching 47 mph (76 km/h).<ref name="92ts4">{{cite web|author=Hurricane Research Division|year=2004|title=Observations for Tropical Storm Four in 1892|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/excelfiles_centerfix/1892/1892_4.XLS|format=XLS}}</ref> *October 24, 1892 – Heavy rainfall is reported in southern Florida as a result of a tropical storm hitting [[Tampa Bay]].<ref name="1892mwr"/> *June 16, 1893 – [[St. Marks, Florida|Saint Marks]] is struck by a tropical storm. Moderate winds and rainfall occurs throughout the northeastern portion of the state,<ref name="1893mwr">{{cite web|author=United States Weather Bureau|year=1893|title=Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1893.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> including a total of 1.51 inches in [[Jacksonville, Florida|Jacksonville]].<ref name="aoml"/> *August 27, 1893 – The [[1893 Sea Islands Hurricane|Sea Islands Hurricane]] parallels the eastern coastline as a major hurricane, producing winds in excess of 75 mph (120 km/h) near the coast. The winds destroy nine cottages in [[Naval Station Mayport|Mayport]].<ref name="aoml"/> *October 2, 1893 – The [[1893 Cheniere Caminada Hurricane|Cheniere Caminada Hurricane]] makes landfall on southeastern [[Louisiana]], though its large and powerful circulation damages [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]] with high tides and winds.<ref name="1893mwr"/> *October 12, 1893 – A major hurricane parallels the coastline about 60 miles (95 km) offshore. The [[storm tide]] was high enough that at low tide, it was at the position of the normal high tide mark. The tide caused street flooding in [[St. Augustine, Florida|Saint Augustine]], with heavy damage reported in [[Naval Station Mayport|Mayport]].<ref name="aoml"/> *August 7, 1894 – The second storm of the season hits just west of the Florida/[[Alabama]] border. [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]] reports 50 mph (80 km/h) winds in association with the storm, though damage, if any, is unknown.<ref name="84ts2">{{cite web|author=Hurricane Research Division|year=2004|title=Observations for Tropical Storm Two of 1894|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/excelfiles_centerfix/1894/1894_2.XLS|format=XLS}}</ref> *September 25, 1894 – A hurricane makes landfall near [[Fort Myers, Florida|Fort Myers]]. In [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]], rainfall reached 13.78 inches (350 mm), causing coastal flooding in areas.<ref name="1894mwr">{{cite web|author=United States Weather Bureau|year=1894|title=Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1894.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> Heavy damage was reported in several cities in northeastern Florida.<ref name="aoml"/> *October 9, 1894 – A major hurricane hits moves ashore near [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]], producing high tides and heavy rainfall.<ref name="1894mwr"/> *October 2, 1895 – Heavy rainfall occurs in southern Florida as a result of a tropical storm passing a short distance to the south of the state.<ref name="1895mwr">{{cite web|author=United States Weather Bureau|year=1895|title=Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1895.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *October 16, 1895 – [[Naples, Florida|Naples]] is struck by a tropical storm whose impact is unknown.{{hurdat}} *October 22, 1895 – An offshore hurricane causes high tides and strong winds in southeastern Florida.<ref name="1895mwr"/> *July 7, 1896 – A [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 2]] hurricane hits near [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]]. There, strong winds destroy the roofs of about 35 houses and wreck 9 boats. Damage in the city is estimated at over $100,000 (1896 USD, $2.6 million 2008 USD).<ref name="1896mwr">{{cite web|author=United States Weather Bureau|year=1896|title=Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1896.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *September 29, 1896 – The [[1896 Cedar Keys hurricane|fourth storm]] makes landfall as a major hurricane on [[Yankeetown, Florida|Yankeetown]] with a pressure of 960 [[Bar (unit)|mbar]]. Strong winds downed hundreds of trees and caused severe damage amounting to $1.5 million (1896 USD, $36 million 2006 USD).<ref name="1896mwr"/> Multiple deaths were reported in the state.<ref name="deadliest"/> *October 9, 1896 – A tropical storm hits near [[Fort Myers, Florida|Fort Myers]], though its impact is unknown.{{hurdat}} *September 11, 1897 – An anemometer in [[Pensacola, Florida|Pensacola]] reports winds of 43 mph (69 km/h) from a hurricane in the [[Gulf of Mexico]]. It is unknown if the hurricane causes damage in the state.<ref name="97h2">{{cite web|author=Hurricane Research Division|year=2004|title=Observations for Hurricane Two in 1897|publisher=NOAA|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/excelfiles_centerfix/1897/1897_2.XLS|format=XLS}}</ref> *September 21, 1897 – The third storm of the season moves ashore just north of Fort Myers and produces heavy rainfall, including a 24‑hour total of 6.56 inches (166 mm) in [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]].<ref>{{cite web|author=United States Weather Bureau|year=1897|title=Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1897.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> [[Image:San Ciriaco Hurricane SWA (1899).JPG|right|200px|thumb|Surface weather analysis for the San Ciriaco Hurricane on August 13, 1899]] *August 2, 1898 – A tropical storm makes landfall near [[Palm Beach, Florida|Palm Beach]], crosses the state, and intensifies in the [[Gulf of Mexico]] before hitting [[Apalachicola, Florida|Apalachicola]] as a hurricane. Three barges, four tug boats, and several boats are destroyed, and numerous wharves and dwellings are damaged as a result of the storm. Four people die from the shipwrecks.<ref name="1898mwr">{{cite web|author=United States Weather Bureau|year=1898|title=Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1898.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *October 2, 1898 – A [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 4]] hurricane hits southern [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], causing severe damage in the extreme northeastern portion of the state. A [[storm surge]] of 12 feet floods and damages several buildings along the [[Fernandina Beach, Florida|Fernandina]] waterfront.<ref name="aoml"/> A conservative estimate for total damage in the state is $500,000 (1898 USD, $13 million 2008 USD).<ref name="1898mwr"/> *August 1, 1899 – After previously moving across southwestern Florida, a [[Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Scale|Category 2]] hurricane strikes [[Apalachicola, Florida|Apalachicola]]. The storm causes $575,000 in boat, crop, and property damage (1899 USD, $14.8 million 2008 USD), and also results in six fatalities.<ref name="1899mwr">{{cite web|author=United States Weather Bureau|year=1899|title=Monthly Weather Review|accessdate=2007-01-15|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/mwr_pdf/1899.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> *August 13, 1899 – The [[1899 Hurricane San Ciriaco|San Ciriaco Hurricane]] parallels the eastern coastline, producing moderate winds and light damage.<ref name="1899mwr"/> *October 5, 1899 – A tropical storm hits near [[Tampa, Florida|Tampa]] and sinks a schooner off [[Fernandina Beach, Florida|Fernandina Beach]].<ref name="aoml"/> *October 30, 1899 – A hurricane parallels the eastern Florida coastline, with several locations near the coast recording strong winds in association with the storm. No cases of serious damage are reported.<ref name="1899mwr"/>

Murray & Elven</small> – Holmgren's cinquefoil *''[[Potentilla jepsonii]]'' <small>Ertter</small> *''[[Potentilla johnstonii]]'' <small>Soják</small> – sagebrush cinquefoil *''[[Potentilla lasiodonta]]'' <small>Rydb.</small> – Sandhills cinquefoil *''[[Potentilla litoralis]]'' <small>Rydb.</small> – Pennsylvania cinquefoil *''[[Potentilla macounii]]'' <small>Rydb.</small> – Macoun's cinquefoil *''[[Potentilla modesta]]'' <small>Rydb.</small> – Uintah cinquefoil *''[[Potentilla multijuga]]'' <small>Lehm.</small> – Ballona cinquefoil *''[[Potentilla nana]]'' <small>Willd. ex Schltdl.</small> – arctic cinquefoil *''[[Potentilla × nubilans]]'' <small>Soják</small> *''[[Potentilla paucijuga]]'' <small>Rydb.</small> – La Sal cinquefoil *''[[Potentilla pedersenii]]'' <small>(Rydb.) Rydb.</small> *''[[Potentilla puberula]]'' <small>Krasan</small> *''[[Potentilla rhyolitica]]'' <small>Ertter</small> *''[[Potentilla rupestris]]'' <small>L.</small> *''[[Potentilla sanguinea]]'' <small>Rydb.</small> – scarlet cinquefoil *''[[Potentilla saximontana]]'' <small>Rydb.</small> *''[[Potentilla sierrae-blancae]]'' <small>Wooton & Rydb.</small> – Sierra Blanca cinquefoil *''[[Potentilla subgorodkovii]]'' <small>Jurtzev</small> *''[[Potentilla townsendii]]'' <small>Rydb.</small> – Townsend's cinquefoil *''[[Potentilla × tundricola]]'' <small>Soják</small> *''[[Potentilla uschakovii]]'' <small>Jurtzev</small> *''[[Potentilla verna]]'' <small>L.</small> – spring cinquefoil *''[[Potentilla versicolor]]'' <small>Rydb.</small> – Steens Mountain cinquefoil *''[[Potentilla wheeleri]]'' <small>S. Watson</small> – Kern cinquefoil {{div col end}}
==GRIN list== The following additional species are accepted by the [[Germplasm Resources Information Network]] (GRIN), although they might be considered synonyms by other sources, or be erroneous accessions:<ref>{{cite web |url=https://npgsweb.ars-grin.gov/gringlobal/taxonomylist.aspx?category=species&type=genus&value=Potentilla&id=9797 |title=''Potentilla'' |publisher=Germplasm Resources Information Network |accessdate=19 July 2018}}</ref> {{div col|colwidth=24em}} *''[[Potentilla curviseta]]'' *''[[Potentilla dickinsii]]'' *''[[Potentilla dombeyi]]'' *''[[Potentilla gelida]]'' *''[[Potentilla hebiichigo]]'' *''[[Potentilla hemsleyana]]'' *''[[Potentilla indica]]'' *''[[Potentilla ledebouriana]]'' *''[[Potentilla nudicaulis]]'' *''[[Potentilla paradoxa]]'' *''[[Potentilla ranunculus]]'' *''[[Potentilla rubicaulis]]'' *''[[Potentilla siemersiana]]'' *''[[Potentilla sundaica]]'' *''[[Potentilla togasii]]'' *''[[Potentilla tridentata]]'' {{div col end}}
==Others== *''[[Potentilla sterneri]]'' is newly described
==References== {{reflist}} {{Commonscat|position=left|Potentilla}}

revision.comment: /* N */ Removed Senecio nikoensis, now in Nemesenecio

page.title: List of Superfund sites in Florida

revision.text:
This is a '''list of Superfund sites in Florida''' designated under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) environmental law. The CERCLA federal law of 1980 authorized the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) to create a list of [[Pollution|polluted]] locations requiring a long-term response to clean up hazardous material contaminations.P.L. 96-510, {{USC|42|9601|9675}}), December 11, 1980. These locations are known as [[Superfund]] sites, and are placed on the [[National Priorities List]] (NPL). The NPL guides the EPA in "determining which sites warrant further investigation" for [[environmental remediation]]. As of May 3, 2010, there were 52 Superfund sites on the National Priorities List in [[Florida]].{{cite web| url=http://www.epa.gov/superfund/sites/npl/ |title=National Priorities List |publisher=United States Environmental Protection Agency |accessdate=2010-05-01}} Three more sites have been proposed for entry on the list and 23 others have been cleaned up and removed from it. There are also twelve Superfund Alternative sites in the state.{{cite web | title=Region 4 Superfund Sites | publisher=EPA | url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/index.htm#FL | accessdate=2010-05-05}} ==Superfund sites== :{{legend2|#fcf75e|Proposed for addition to National Priorities List|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} :{{legend2|#d0f0c0|Deleted from National Priorities List|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} :{{legend2|#add8e6|Superfund Alternative site|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center" |- !CERCLIS ID !Name !County !Reason !Proposed !Listed{{cite web|title=Final NPL sites| publisher=EPA|url=http://www.epa.gov/superfund/sites/query/queryhtm/nplfin.htm| accessdate=2010-05-04}} !Construction
completed{{cite web|title=Construction Completions at NPL sites| publisher=EPA|url=http://www.epa.gov/superfund/sites/query/queryhtm/nplccl.htm| accessdate=2010-05-04}} !Partially
deleted{{cite web|title=Partial deletions at NPL sites| publisher=EPA|url=http://www.epa.gov/superfund/sites/query/queryhtm/nplpdel.htm| accessdate=2010-05-04}} !Deleted{{cite web|title=Deleted NPL sites| publisher=EPA|url=http://www.epa.gov/superfund/sites/query/queryhtm/npldel.htm| accessdate=2010-05-04}} |- | FLD980221857 || [[Agrico Chemical Co.]] || [[Escambia County, Florida|Escambia]] ||{{left}} Soil and surface water contamination by [[fluoride]], [[arsenic]] and [[lead]] and groundwater contamination by [[fluoride]], [[arsenic]], [[chloride]], [[sulfate]], [[nitrate]]/[[nitrite]], [[radium-226]] and [[radium-228]] from former chemical and fertilizer manufacturing.{{cite web|title=Agrico Chemical Co. site summary |publisher=EPA |url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfln/agricofl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110207030058/http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfln/agricofl.htm |archivedate=2011-02-07 |df= }} || 06/24/1988 || 10/04/1989 || 09/23/1999 || – || – |- | FLD004145140 || [[Airco Plating Co.]] || [[Miami-Dade County, Florida|Miami-Dade]] ||{{left}} Soil and groundwater contamination by metals, including [[cadmium]] and [[chromium]], and [[VOCs]], including [[tetrachloroethylene|PCE]], [[dichloroethylene|DCE]] and [[vinyl chloride]]. There is a risk of contamination of the [[Biscayne Aquifer]], the county's sole drinking water source.{{cite web|title=Airco Plating Co. site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfls/aircopfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 06/24/1988 || 02/21/1990 || 09/15/1999 || – || – |- | FLD012978862 || [[Alaric Area Groundwater Plume]] || [[Hillsborough County, Florida|Hillsborough]] ||{{left}} Groundwater contamination by [[tetrachloroethylene|PCE]] and [[trichloroethylene|TCE]], including trace contamination of the [[Floridan Aquifer|Upper Floridan Aquifer]], a major source of drinking water in the Tampa area. Contamination has also spread to the nearby Helena Chemical Superfund site.{{cite web|title=Alaric Area Groundwater Plume site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfls/alaricfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 02/04/2000 || 12/01/2000 || 09/30/2003 || – || – |-style="background:#d0f0c0" | FLD041495441 || [[Alpha Chemical Corp.]] || [[Polk County, Florida|Polk]] ||{{left}} Groundwater, soil and sediment contamination by [[VOCs]], including [[xylene]], [[styrene]], [[ethylbenzene]], [[benzoic acid]] and 1,2-[[dichloropropane]] from former industrial waste disposal practices.{{cite web|title=Alpha Chemical Corp. site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfls/alphacfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 12/30/1982 || 09/08/1983 || 09/21/1990 || – || 06/28/1995 |- | FLD008161994 || [[American Creosote Works (Pensacola Plt)]] || [[Escambia County, Florida|Escambia]] ||{{left}} Soil, sediment and groundwater are contaminated with [[VOCs]], [[PAHs]], [[Pentachlorophenol|PCP]] and [[Polychlorinated dibenzodioxins|dioxins]] from former wood treatment operations.{{cite web|title=American Creosote Works (Pensacola Plt) site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfln/acwpenfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 12/30/1982 || 09/08/1983 || – || – || – |-style="background:#d0f0c0" | FLD020536538 || [[Anaconda Aluminum Co./Milgo Electronics]] || [[Miami-Dade County, Florida|Miami-Dade]] ||{{left}} Groundwater was contaminated by [[cyanide]] and [[heavy metal (chemistry)|heavy metal]]s, such as [[cadmium]], [[lead]], [[iron]], [[zinc]], [[selenium]] and [[copper]] from former on-site waste disposal practices. Sediment, soil and surface water contained heavy metals such as [[mercury (element)|mercury]], selenium and [[arsenic]]. Contamination reached the [[Biscayne Aquifer]], the sole source of drinking water for south Florida.{{cite web|title=Anaconda Aluminum Co./Milgo Electronics site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfls/anacalfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 10/26/1989 || 08/30/1990 || 11/22/1994 || – || 07/09/1998 |- | FLD981014368 || [[Anodyne, Inc.]] || [[Miami-Dade County, Florida|Miami-Dade]] ||{{left}} Groundwater contamination by metals and [[VOCs]] and soil contaminated by [[metals]] from former manufacturing operations.{{cite web|title=Anodyne, Inc. site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfls/anodynfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 06/24/1988 || 02/21/1990 || – || – || – |- | FLSFN0406909 || [[Arkla Terra Property]] || [[Polk County, Florida|Polk]] ||{{left}} Soil, groundwater and private drinking water wells are contaminated by [[tetrachloroethylene|PCE]] from tank cleaning.{{cite web|title=Arkla Terra Property site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfls/arklaterfls.html |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 06/29/2008 || 04/09/2009 || – || – || – |- | FLD004574190 || [[B&B Chemical Co., Inc.]] || [[Miami-Dade County, Florida|Miami-Dade]] ||{{left}} Soil and groundwater contamination by [[benzene]], [[chlorobenzene]] and [[vinyl chloride]] from soakage pits. The site has impacted the [[Biscayne Aquifer]], the sole source of drinking water in southern Florida.{{cite web|title=B&B Chemical Co., Inc. site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfls/b&bchmfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 06/24/1988 || 08/30/1990 || 10/01/1994 || – || – |-style="background:#d0f0c0" | FLD980494660 || [[Beulah Landfill]] || [[Escambia County, Florida|Escambia]] ||{{left}} Groundwater contamination by [[pentachlorophenol|PCP]] and soils and sludges contaminated by [[PAHs]], [[pesticide]]s, PCP and metals, including [[aluminum]], [[zinc]], [[iron]], [[lead]], [[chromium]] and [[nickel]].{{cite web|title=Beulah Landfill site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfln/beulahfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 06/26/1988 || 02/21/1990 || 09/16/1993 || – || 06/22/1998 |-style="background:#d0f0c0" | FLD052172954 || [[BMI-Textron]] || [[Palm Beach County, Florida|Palm Beach]] ||{{left}} Soil was containated by [[cyanide]] and [[fluoride]]; groundwater was contaminated by [[arsenic]], cyanide, fluoride and [[sodium]].{{cite web|title=BMI-Textron site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfls/bmitexfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 06/24/1988 || 08/30/1990 || 08/11/1994 || – || 11/18/2002 |-style="background:#add8e6" | FLD980847016 || [[Brown's Dump]] || [[Duval County, Florida|Duval]] ||{{left}} Soil contained elevated levels of [[lead]], [[arsenic]], other [[inorganic compound]]s, [[organic compounds]], [[pesticide]]s, [[PCBs]], [[Polychlorinated dibenzodioxins|dioxins]] and [[furan]]s. Remedial action is expected to start in 2010.{{cite web|title=Brown's Dump site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfln/brndmppr.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || – || – || – || – || – |-style="background:#d0f0c0" | FLD980728935 || [[Brown Wood Preserving]] || [[Suwannee County, Florida|Suwannee]] ||{{left}} Soil and sediments were contaminated by carcinogenic [[PAHs]] from former wood treatment operations.{{cite web|title=Brown Wood Preserving site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfln/brwnwdfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 12/30/1982 || 09/08/1983 || 12/31/1991 || – || 09/22/1995 |- | FLD980709356 || [[Cabot/Koppers]] || [[Alachua County, Florida|Alachua]] ||{{left}} The Cabot part of the site is a former charcoal production operation, which is now redeveloped; the Koppers part is a former wood treatment facility. Groundwater, soil and possibly off-site surface water are contaminated by [[arsenic]], [[PAHs]] and [[creosote]] compounds, from poor waste-handling practices in the past.{{cite web|title=Cabot/Koppers site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfln/cabkopfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 09/08/1983 || 09/21/1984 || – || – || – |-style="background:#d0f0c0" | FLD094590916 || [[Callaway & Son Drum Service]] || [[Polk County, Florida|Polk]] ||{{left}} Groundwater is contaminated by [[dichloroethylene|DCE]], [[trichloroethylene|TCE]], [[tetrachloroethylene|PCE]], [[xylene]] and [[vinyl chloride]] from former drum cleaning operations at levels not thought to pose a risk. Contaminated drums have been removed from the site.{{cite web|title=Callaway & Son Drum Service site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfls/callawfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 02/04/2000 || 05/11/2000 || 12/21/2007 || – || 08/04/2009 |-style="background:#add8e6" | FLD981931959 || [[Cascade Park Gasification Plant/Landfill]] || [[Leon County, Florida|Leon]] ||{{left}} Soil and groundwater contamination by light and heavy oils, [[coal tar]]s, sludges, ash, [[ammonia]], [[cyanide]] and [[lime (material)|lime]] wastes{{cite web|title=Cascade Park Gasification Plant/Landfill site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfln/cascadfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || – || – || – || – || – |- | FL5170022474 || [[Cecil Field Naval Air Station]] || [[Duval County, Florida|Duval]] ||{{left}} Release of [[petroleum]] products, [[solvent]]s, [[corrosive]]s, [[compressed gas]]ses, [[pesticide]]s, [[paint]]s and [[paint thinner|thinners]] from spills and poor housekeeping practices at the former base.{{cite web|title=Cecil Field Naval Air Station site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfln/cecnasfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 07/14/1989 || 11/21/1989 || 08/26/2009 || 05/21/2003 || – |-style="background:#d0f0c0" | FLD080174402 || [[Chemform, Inc.]] || [[Broward County, Florida|Broward]] ||{{left}} Soil and groundwater were contaminated by [[vinyl chloride]], [[arsenic]], [[chromium]] and other substances from disposal practices at a former precision machine shop.{{cite web|title=Chemform, Inc. site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfls/chmfrmfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 06/10/1988 || 10/04/1989 || 09/16/1993 || – || 07/28/2000 |- | FLD004064242 || [[Chevron Chemical Co. (Ortho Division)]] || [[Orange County, Florida|Orange]] ||{{left}} Soil and groundwater contamination by [[pesticide]]s, [[petroleum]] products and [[VOCs]], including [[xylene]] from waste disposal practices at a former pesticide formulation plant. Contaminated soil has been removed.{{cite web|title=Chevron Chemical Co. (Ortho Division) site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfls/chevrnfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 01/18/1994 || 05/31/1994 || 02/10/1998 || – || – |- | FLD055945653 || [[City Industries, Inc.]] || [[Orange County, Florida|Orange]] ||{{left}} Soil and groundwater contamination by poor waste handling processes and intentional dumping by a former industrial waste handling business. The site was abandoned with around 1,200 drums of hazardous waste and thousands of gallons of sludge in storage tanks. Wastes and contaminated soil were removed in 1983–4; groundwater is being treated.{{cite web|title=City Industries, Inc. site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfls/cityinfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 10/15/1984 || 10/04/1989 || 03/02/1994 || – || – |- | FLD991279894 || [[Coleman-Evans Wood Preserving Co.]] || [[Duval County, Florida|Duval]] ||{{left}} Soil, sediment and shallow groundwater were contaminated by [[pentachlorophenol|PCP]] and [[Polychlorinated dibenzodioxins|dioxins]] from former wood treatment operations. Over {{convert|210,000|ST|t}} of soil have been treated, around 320,000 gallons of hazardous liquids have been recovered and safely disposed of, over 2,000 cubic yards of hazardous solids have been safely disposed of and over 73,000,000 gallons of groundwater have been treated and discharged.{{cite web|title=Coleman-Evans Wood Preserving Co. site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfln/colevafl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 12/30/1982 || 09/08/1983 || 09/18/2007 || – || – |-style="background:#add8e6" | FLD001704741 || [[Coronet Industries]] || [[Hillsborough County, Florida|Hillsborough]] ||{{left}} [[Organic compound|Organic]] and [[inorganic compound|inorganic]] contamination from former [[phosphate]] mine and processing plant is under investigation.{{cite web|title=Coronet Industries site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfls/coronetfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || – || – || – || – || – |-style="background:#d0f0c0" | FLD980602288 || [[Davie Landfill]] || [[Broward County, Florida|Broward]] ||{{left}} Soils, sludges and groundwater contaminated by [[inorganic compound]]s, [[heavy metal (chemistry)|heavy metal]]s and [[VOCs]]. The primary contaminants of concern for groundwater are [[vinyl chloride]] and [[antimony]]. Sludges have been dewatered and stabilized and groundwater contamination has attenuated to levels not thought to pose a risk to health.{{cite web|title=Davie Landfill site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfls/davilffl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 12/30/1982 || 09/08/1983 || 11/08/1995 || – || 08/21/2006 |-style="background:#d0f0c0" | FLD000833368 || [[Dubose Oil Products Co.]] || [[Escambia County, Florida|Escambia]] ||{{left}} Soil was contaminated by [[VOCs]], [[PAHs]] and [[pentachlorophenol|PCP]] and groundwater by VOCs, from a former waste processing facility. After cleanup, no hazardous substances remain on site at levels considered harmful.{{cite web|title=Dubose Oil Products Co. site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfln/dubosefl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 10/15/1984 || 06/10/1986 || 09/11/1997 || – || 10/01/2004 |- | FLD008168346 || [[Escambia Wood – Pensacola]] || [[Escambia County, Florida|Escambia]] ||{{left}} [[Creosote]], [[pentachlorophenol|PCP]], [[PAHs|PAH]] and [[Polychlorinated dibenzodioxins|dioxin]] contamination from an abandoned wood treatment facility. Adjacent properties are contaminated by PCP and dioxins and groundwater by PCP and [[naphthalene]]. Most of an estimated 358 affected households have been permanently relocated.{{cite web|title=Escambia Wood – Pensacola site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfln/escwodfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 08/23/1994 || 12/16/1994 || – || – || – |- | FLD083111005 || [[Flash Cleaners]] || [[Broward County, Florida|Broward]] ||{{left}} Soil, sludge and groundwater contaminated by [[tetrachloroethene|PCE]], [[trichloroethene|TCE]] and decomposition products from former on-site dry cleaning operations.{{cite web|title=Flash Cleaners site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfls/flashclfls.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 03/19/2008 || 09/03/2008 || – || – || – |- | FLD984184127 || [[Florida Petroleum Reprocessors]] || [[Broward County, Florida|Broward]] ||{{left}} Extensive [[VOCs|VOC]] groundwater pollution from a former waste oil processing facility has contaminated the [[Biscayne Aquifer]]. Soil is contaminated by VOCs and waste oil degradation products and there is a highly concentrated non-aqueous phase layer.{{cite web|title=Florida Petroleum Reprocessors site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfls/flpetrfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 04/01/1997 || 03/06/1998 || – || – || – |- | FLD050432251 || [[Florida Steel Corp.]] || [[Martin County, Florida|Martin]] ||{{left}} Soil was contaminated by [[lead]], [[zinc]] from disposal of dust filtered from the air in the mill and by [[PCBs]] from hydraulic fluid leaks. Groundwater is contaminated by [[sodium]] from a water softening plant and [[radium]], which may be naturally occurring but may have been concentrated by operation of the water softener. The steel mill has not operated since 1982.{{cite web|title=Florida Steel Corp. site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfls/flastlfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 12/30/1982 || 09/08/1983 || 09/11/1997 || – || – |-style="background:#fcf75e" | FLR000091322 || [[General Dynamics Longwood]] ||[[Seminole County, Florida|Seminole]] ||{{left}} Soil is contaminated by [[trichloroethylene|TCE]] and breakdown products, [[arsenic]], [[cadmium]], [[lead]], [[mercury (element)|mercury]] and [[silver]] and groundwater by TCE and breakdown products, and [[chromium]] from former printed circuit board manufacture and other operations. The shallow aquifer is connected to the Upper [[Floridan Aquifer]].{{cite web|title=General Dynamics Longwood site listing narrative |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/superfund/sites/npl/nar1796.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 04/09/2009 || – || – || – || – |-style="background:#d0f0c0" | FLD071307680 || [[Gold Coast Oil Corp.]] || [[Miami-Dade County, Florida|Miami-Dade]] ||{{left}} Soil was contaminated by [[VOCs]] and metals from improper waste disposal at a former oil and solvent reclamation facility. Groundwater, including the [[Biscayne Aquifer]], which is the sole source of drinking water for southern Florida, was contaminated by VOCs.{{cite web|title=Gold Coast Oil Corp. site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfls/gldcstfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 12/30/1982 || 09/08/1983 || 06/23/1992 || – || 10/09/1996 |- | FLD000602334 || [[Harris Corp. (Palm Bay Plant)]] || [[Brevard County, Florida|Brevard]] ||{{left}} Groundwater was contaminated by numerous substances, including [[vinyl chloride]], [[trichloroethene|TCE]] and [[chromium]]. The adjacent municipal well field was contaminated.{{cite web|title=Harris Corp. (Palm Bay Plant) site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfls/harrisfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 04/10/1985 || 07/22/1987 || 07/01/1998 || – || – |- | FLD053502696 || [[Helena Chemical Co. (Tampa Plant)]] || [[Hillsborough County, Florida|Hillsborough]] ||{{left}} Soil is contaminated by [[pesticide]]s, semi-VOCs and [[VOCs]], including [[xylene]], from former operations on site. Groundwater is contaminated by [[chlorinated pesticides]], [[PAHs]], [[phenol]]s and [[VOCs]].{{cite web|title=Helena Chemical Co. (Tampa Plant) site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfls/helenafl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 02/07/1992 || 10/14/1992 || – || – || – |- | FLD980709802 || [[Hipps Road Landfill]] || [[Duval County, Florida|Duval]] ||{{left}} A former landfill site was redeveloped into residential lots. Groundwater is contaminated by [[VOCs]], including [[vinyl chloride]] and [[benzene]].{{cite web|title=Hipps Road Landfill site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfln/hipprdfl.html |accessdate=2010-05-05}} || 09/08/1983 || 09/21/1984 || 09/02/1994 || – || – |- | FLD004119681 || [[Hollingsworth Solderless Terminal]] || [[Broward County, Florida|Broward]] ||{{left}} Soil and groundwater contamination by [[VOCs]] from the discharge of degreasing agents.{{cite web|title=Hollingsworth Solderless Terminal site summary Groundwater contamination is mixed with contamination from the nearby [[Miami Drum Services]] and [[Northwest 58th Street Landfill]] Superfund sites and has reached the [[Biscayne Aquifer]], the county's sole source of drinking water.{{cite web|title=Varsol Oil Spill site summary |publisher=EPA| url=http://www.epa.gov/region4/waste/npl/nplfls/varsolfl.htm |accessdate=2010-05-24}} ||
